elements.text: PART ONE
PRE-CREDITS:
SCENE 1. INT. ADRIC’S HOUSE.
FX: A THUNDERSTORM IS IN PROGRESS. HEAVY RAIN. FUTURISTIC
VEHICLES WHIRR PAST; AN ALIEN WORLD WITH BAD WEATHER.
(NARRATION) I can still remember that night as though it were yesterday. It was Quintilis the first in the year thirty-five thirty-one, and I was studying alone at home on Zarat...
FX: WE MOVE INDOORS. THUNDERSTORM IS MUFFLED. RAIN PATTERS ON
WINDOWS. A COMPUTER SOFTLY CHIMES.
Comm-link request. Professor Lasarti.
(AGED ABOUT 15. EXCITED) Accept request, open comm-link!
FX: COMPUTER CHIMES. THE LINK IS HEAVY WITH INTERFERENCE.
Father? Have you found her? (BEAT) Father-?
(VIA LINK) There is no easy way to say this, my son. I’m afraid... the reconnaissance satellite failed to find any signs of life.
What? B-but —
(VIA LINK)
It sent back pictures of the remains of the research station... and your mother’s scout ship. There must have been some kind of accident.
Then she must still be there, somewhere the satellite can’t see her!
(VIA LINK) I’m sorry, my son, but there can no longer be any doubt about it. She’s dead.
No... No!
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 3
(VIA LINK) Listen. The comm-link won’t last much longer. I need you to tell your sister for me. Tell Neeka.
M-me-? Father, I can’t!
(VIA LINK) I’ll be back within ten days. I’1l come and visit you both as soon as I return. Goodbye, Adric.
What? Don’t go, father! [Please —]
FX: THE LINK CUTS OUT LEAVING ADRIC ALONE WITH THE SOUNDS OF
THE STORM.
(BREAKING DOWN) No. She can’t be dead. She can’t!
OPENING THEME
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 4
SCENE 2. INT. LABORATORY.
FX: EQUIPMENT BLEEPING, GURGLING AND THRUMMING. AN EXPERIMENT
IS BEING CONDUCTED ON A SEMI-SEDATED PATIENT.
Extracting blood sample... now.
JABBED — MOAN OF PAIN
Commencing analysis.
FX: GADGET BLEEPS.
Anti-viral compound proved... ineffective. Subject remains infected.
GROANS SOFTLY
What? But that’s impossible.
Look for yourself. All the markers for Richter’s Syndrome. The anti-viral compound failed.
(DEFEATED) Have the subject placed in cryogen storage with the others.
FX: BLEEP AS SHE USES A GADGET TO SEND THE PATIENT TO SLEEP.
SIGHS AND GOES QUIET
And Mahandra? Instruct the Alcazar to put out another appeal for ‘volunteers’.
I’d be more comfortable if our experimental subjects weren’t all convicted prisoners.
Better than experimenting upon innocent citizens. Besides, when we do find the cure, we’ll simply revive them and cure them, along with the rest of the galaxy.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 5
But in the meantime, we have a cryogen chamber packed to the rafters with convicts infected with Richter’s. By you.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 3. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
FX: TARDIS MATERIALISATION PING.
Oh. I was expecting it to be a little bumpier. Evidently whatever it was that forced us down had a much greater degree of control.
Forced us down where?
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED.
An Earth-type planet, with normal gravity and a breathable atmosphere.
FX: SCANNER OPENS. SOUNDS OF MEDIEVAL MARKETPLACE.
A fortress. Surrounded by a small town.
Looks positively medieval. Like a painting by Brueghel.
Not quite. The buildings are fitted with microwave antennae, probably a way of harvesting ambient electromagnetic energy. Fairly advanced, by the look of it.
There are also rather a lot of security cameras pointing in our
direction.
Yes, I had noticed.
FX: VIA SCANNER, COMMITTEE OF SIX MEN APPROACHING, CHATTERING.
And I guess they must be the welcoming committee.
They seem friendly enough. Shall we pop out and say hello?
FX: DOOR OPENS.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 4. EXT. TOWN STREET (CONTINUOUS)
FX: CHICKENS CLUCK, CATTLE SNORTS, TRADERS PATTER, EXOTIC
BUSKERS. TARDIS DOOR OPENS, DOCTOR AND FRIENDS EMERGE. THE GROUND IS MUDDY, PUDDLES. OMINOUS CHIMING BELLS RING OUT.
Ah. Everyone, mind where you’re treading.
You could’ve warned me about the smell. It’s worse than my dad’s farm.
You'll get used to it.
Yeah, right. If I don’t pass out first.
(POLITE COUGH) If I am not interrupting —
(PROMPTING) Ah, Doctor, the welcoming committee?
FX: DOCTOR CLOSES TARDIS DOOR.
Oh, yes. Hello! Hope you don’t mind us dropping in on you like this.
Not at all. You are most welcome.
You don’t seem very surprised to see us.
Why should we be?
A British police box, appearing out of thin air in a back- alley. That happen a lot around here?
(POLITE LAUGH) No. But you see, we had advance notice of your arrival.
You did?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 8
It was foretold.
How terribly interesting. Foretold by whom, exactly?
FX: CROSS TO:
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 5. INT. LABORATORY (CONTINUOUS)
FX: ADRIC IS WATCHING VIA A MONITOR. THE SOUND QUALITY VARIES,
LIKE A TV BEING TUNED IN.
(VIA MONITOR) Forgive me, I have neglected to introduce myself. I am Sibor, Prime Elector of this colony.
[TURLOUGH: (VIA MONITOR) Which means you’re in charge?
(VIA MONITOR) Quite. This is Deputy Elector Cartock, and Deputy Elector Mogal. ]
FX: OVER THE LAST TWO LINES, WE HEAR A DOOR RATTLE OPEN AS
MAHANDRA ENTERS.
Adric, what are you doing?
The security network detected a quarantine breach.
So what? That’s nothing to do with us. If Sibor found out you’d hacked into the network —
I just wanted to see who they were.
What’s that thing they’ve brought with them, that blue crate?
I don’t know. For a moment I thought... no, but it can’t be.
FX: WE RETURN TO THE CONVERSATION ON THE MONITOR. ADRIC TUNES
IT IN BETTER SO THE QUALITY IMPROVES.
(VIA MONITOR) I’m the Doctor... or did you know that already?
(VIA MONITOR) Not your name, no.
FX: AUDIO QUALITY NOW VERY CLEAR.
(VIA MONITOR) And these are my friends, Tegan. Turlough... And Nyssa.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 10
(VIA MONITOR) You mentioned that this world is a colony? An Earth colony?
(VIA MONITOR) That is correct. The first settlers arrived here on Valderon [over a hundred years ago.
(VIA MONITOR) Must say, you’ve made quite a go of it. Using local building materials, nice authentic touch.
(VIA MONITOR) Simply the most effective approach. We have to be as self- sufficient as possible. ]
FX: WHILE THIS CONVERSATION IS GOING ON IN B/G OUR FOCUS IS ON
THE FOLLOWING IN THE FOREGROUND, FROM SIBOR SAYING ‘OVER A HUNDRED YEARS AGO.’
Nyssa... Oh my worship. It’s her. It’s her!
What’s the matter? You’re shaking, like you’ve seen a ghost.
There, on the screen. She’s.. m-my mother.
But I thought —
Shhh!
FX: CROSS TO:
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 11
SCENE 6. EXT. TOWN STREET (CONTINUOUS)
You wouldn’t be able to tell us the year, would you?
The year?
One of the disadvantages of faster-than-light travel, you’re never quite sure how much time has elapsed.
The year is thirty-five fifty-six.
What’s with all the cameras and the big fortress? Expecting trouble?
The fortress? Oh, you mean the Alcazar. No. That is our penitentiary. Our prison.
Prison?
This planet was initially settled as a penal colony, to house the most dangerous criminals from across the Earth empire.
Must make you feel right at home, Tegan.
Very funny.
You still haven’t explained how you knew we would come here.
All will be revealed in due course. If you and your friends would care to accompany me, the Elector’s residence isn’t far.
FX: THEY ALL WALK OFF. CROSS TO:
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 7. INT. LABORATORY (CONTINUOUS)
FX: THEY WATCH THEM GO, THEN ADRIC SWITCHES OFF THE MONITOR.
But I thought your mother was dead. That girl, she must be twenty years younger than you!
You don’t understand. When my mother was a young woman, she travelled in a machine called the TARDIS. A time machine.
A time machine?
I know it’s hard to believe, but when I was a boy she used to tell me stories about the adventures she had when she travelled with the Doctor.
And while she was travelling with the Doctor, she came here, now?
Yes. This must be at a point in her life before I was born.
So, did she ever tell you about the time she came here?
No. And she never mentioned meeting me, as a grown man.
Maybe she forgot?
No. She must’ve avoided mentioning it for a reason. I remember her telling me about the dangers of altering history. That once something has happened, it can’t, mustn’t be changed.
So?
So when she came here, she can’t have met me, or she’d have told me about it. So I can’t meet her now.
But if she’s your mother, don’t you want to speak to her?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 13
Don’t you understand? I can’t. That would create a contradiction, a time paradox.
There is one way you can speak to her.
What?
You don’t tell her who you are.
I might be twenty-five years older than when she last saw me, but I think she’d still recognise her own son!
Not if he was wearing a mask.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 8. INT. ELECTOR’S RESIDENCE
FX: FADE UP. ENTRY CODE, THEN HEAVY DOORS UNBOLT AND OPEN WITH
MOTORS. INSIDE, THE DOCTOR AND FRIENDS WALK ALONG A STONE- FLOORED CORRIDOR.
Our arrival was predicted by a ‘Chronoscope’?
Indeed. It showed us your craft materializing in the town.
Sorry — you’re saying you’ve got a machine that lets you see into the future?
The Chronoscope foretells events of significance, yes.
FX: THEY’RE NOW CLIMBING STONE STAIRS.
Fascinating. I expect it comes in useful for weather forecasts too?
It enables us to make preparations for any severe atmospheric events, yes.
But surely, in a chaotic system, no prediction can ever been completely accurate.
You’re wrong. The Chronoscope’s predictions are always correct.
Always? Every single time? Without fail?
FX: ANOTHER DOOR OPENS WITH MOTORS. THEY ENTER A RECEPTION ROOM
WITH A TRICKLING FOUNTAIN OR AIR CONDITIONING.
Always. It has brought peace, prosperity and security to this world. Accidents are a thing of the past. Preventable illness is a thing of the past. All forms of crime are a thing of the past.
Because any criminal act can be predicted?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 15
Predicted and prevented, enabling us to bring the would-be perpetrators to justice before the crime has even been committed. It’s the perfect system.
So no-one can ever break the law?
Not quite. In fact, I have to go and chair a judicial hearing at this very moment. If you’d care to wait here, you’1ll be able to observe the proceedings on the viewscreen here.
Well, that would be most kind.
If you’ll excuse me-?
FX: SHE LEAVES, DOOR CLOSING BEHIND HER.
She seems very accommodating.
Yeah. A bit too accommodating, if you ask me. .
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 16
SCENE 9. INT. COURTROOM
FX: FADE UP. HUBBUB OF PUBLIC GALLERY DIES DOWN. NOT A
FUTURISTIC SET-UP. SALEM WITCH TRIALS ATMOSPHERE.
I’m innocent, for worship’s sake. Innocent!
Maintenance engineer Ralvo Kartis. You stand indicted of premeditation to murder. Do you understand the nature of the charge?
Yes, I understand it, you’ve arrested me for something I was never going to do!
Replay the prediction.
FX: RECORDING BEGINS TO PLAY. IT’S A SNEAK PREVIEW OF SCENE 61.
Kartis, please, don’t do this.
I’m sorry. I don’t have any choice.
FX: GUN POWERED UP
You have to die.
No, please, I beg you — stop!
FX: ON THE RECORDING, LASER GUN FIRES. RECORDING ENDS. PUBLIC
GALLERY IS ALARMED.
The prediction is clear. Had you not been detained you would have attempted to kill me.
The Chronoscope’s wrong! Why would I want to kill you?
Maintenance Engineer Kartis. You are hereby declared guilty of premeditation to murder. You are to be detained in the Alcazar for the rest of your natural life. Watchmen — take him away.
FX: AS KARTIS IS DRAGGED AWAY BY HEAVY-BOOTED GUARDS, CROSS TO:
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 10. INT. ELECTOR’S RESIDENCE (CONTINUOUS )
(VIA MONITOR) I wasn’t going to kill you! I wasn’t — [going to]!
FX: COURTROOM FEED CUTS OFF ABRUPTLY.
They sentenced that guy to life just based on a prediction?
Makes you wonder, doesn’t it? If any crime can be predicted, why would anyone attempt to break the law?
But Kartis must’ve thought he’d be able to get away with it, otherwise why would he have planned to shoot Sibor?
Unless the Chronoscope wasn’t telling the whole truth. I wonder what it actually is...
FX: DOOR OPENS. ADRIC ENTERS. ADRIC’S VOICE IS DISGUISED AND/OR
MUFFLED AS HE’S WEARING A FACE MASK.
(MASKED) Forgive me for disturbing you, but Sibor suggested I might keep you company.
And who might you be?
(MASKED) My name is Galen. I am the chief physician of the colony.
Delighted to meet you. I’m the Doctor, this is Tegan, Turlough, and Nyssa.
Hello.
(MASKED) Nyssa. It’s good to meet you.
(WARY) It is..?
‘Galen?’ Named after Galen of Pergamon, I presume?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 18
(MASKED) You are remarkably well-informed, Doctor.
That’s what he said.
What happened to your face? If you don’t mind me asking.
(ADMONISHING) Turlough—!

(MASKED) It’s quite alright. There was an accident in my laboratory involving a vitreous solution. The mask accelerates the healing process. Now: Sibor said you were travellers. And I’m afraid my duties include checking new arrivals for any Signs of infection.
What are you insinuating?
(MASKED) Nothing at all. It’s just that as a small, isolated colony, we can’t be too careful. Don’t worry, the process is entirely non-invasive, thanks to this bio-scanner.
FX: MEDICAL GADGET IS SWITCHED ON.
Well, I can’t see the harm.
Anything to set our hosts’ minds at rest. After all, we are their guests.
FX: GADGET USED, THEN SWITCHED OFF.
(MASKED) Remarkable. According to the scanner, you, Nyssa, and Turlough all have non-terrestrial physiologies and are free of infection.
That’s good to hear.
(MASKED) While you.. Tegan, you are human, but with a micro- biome quite unlike any I’ve seen before.
A what?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 19

(MASKED) According to the scanner, your body contains micro- organisms which have been unknown for over a thousand years, while your DNA lacks any synthetic modification. If I didn’t know better, I would say you were the product of an ancient civilisation.
Well, Tegan here is a bit of a genetic throwback, it’s true.
Thanks a bundle!
(MASKED) Please don’t be offended, but it appears that you are in possession of a selection of immunities which we have since lost. Immunities which could be extremely useful.
Of course — because Tegan has been exposed to diseases since eradicated.
(SARCASTIC) Of course. That’s what growing up in Brisbane does for you.
(MASKED) I would be extremely grateful if you could assist me in my research. It won’t cause you any discomfort, I promise. And it might enable me to save lives.
Doctor?
He’s right, it could save lives.
Well, alright then. If you insist.
(MASKED) If you’d like to follow me, we can begin at once.
FX: THEY LEAVE, DOOR CLOSING BEHIND THEM.
Doctor. Have you forgotten? The TARDIS was brought here by something...
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 20
I haven’t forgotten. But there’s no need to be uncivil, is there?
Doctor. Do you think it’s theoretically possible? For a machine to accurately predict the future?
Well, it seems to have foreseen our arrival. Which it couldn’t possibly have done unless it could genuinely see into the future. Or...
Or it was responsible for bringing us here.
Yes. The thought had occurred.
FX: DOOR OPENS (NOT THE SAME ONE TEGAN LEFT THROUGH).
(SWEEPING IN) My sincere apologies for keeping you all waiting.
Not at all, I realise you must have a busy schedule.
You appear to have lost one of your number?
Tegan just left to assist your chief physician with his research.
Ah, I see. Well. Did you find the judicial hearing instructive?
Most educational, yes. I’d like to learn more about this Chronoscope. It seems a remarkably useful gadget. Wherever did you pick it up?
I’m afraid I’m not at liberty to divulge that information.
Well, you must’ve got it from somewhere.
Unless you built it yourself, of course? Could I at least take a look at it?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 21
That will not be possible. The Chronoscope is held in a secure, secret location.
A secure location from which it transmits its predictions?
Indeed. Whenever it has a prediction, the forecast is relayed to this building.
Whenever it has a prediction? So you don’t actually control it, then?
It makes a prediction whenever a significant event is about to occur.
But you don’t get to decide what constitutes a significant event, do you?
I’m afraid I don’t follow your meaning.
Isn’t it obvious? Your machine only shows you what it wants you to see!
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 22
SCENE 11. INT. LABORATORY
FX: DOOR SWISHES OPEN. ADRIC AND TEGAN ENTER. DOOR SHUTS.
You’re not going to be sticking needles into me, are you?
(MASKED) That won’t be necessary. You see, I’ve brought you here under false pretences.
What?
(MASKED) I wished to speak to you in private. Because I know the truth about you all.
What ‘truth’?
(MASKED) That you travel in time, in a machine called the TARDIS.
Who told you that?
(MASKED) Nyssa. Or rather, she will do. In her future.
I don’t understand.
(MASKED) At some point in her future, Nyssa will leave you, and several years after that, she will tell me about you.
Why should I believe you?
(MASKED) I know about what happened when you visited Earth in the seventeenth century. I know about Omega. I know about the Cybermen, and Adric, who died fighting them.
Okay, so you know Nyssa. You brought me here to tell me that?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 23
(MASKED) No. I brought you here because I need your help. You see, several years after she leaves you, Nyssa will go ona mission to a planet called Helheim.
Yes, I — (STOPS HERSELF) This hasn’t happened yet?

(MASKED) As far as Nyssa is concerned, no. As far as I’m concerned, it happened twenty-five years ago. But after she landed on Helheim there was an... accident. An accident that resulted in the destruction of her scout ship.
Why are you telling me this?
(MASKED) Because you have a time machine. After Nyssa leaves you, you and the Doctor can travel to Helheim, where you can rescue her! You can take her with you!
Wouldn’t that be changing history?
(MASKED) No. Her body was never found, so it wouldn’t change a thing. Well, Tegan? Will you do it?
I’m not doing anything, not until I know exactly who you are, and why what happens to Nyssa matters so much to you.
(MASKED) .. Because I’m her son!
Her son...!
(REMOVING MASK) Enough of this mask! (CLEAR NOW) My name is Adric.
(PRETENDING TO BE SURPRISED) Adric?
She’s my mother. My mother who’s been missing, presumed dead, Since I was fifteen years old!
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 12. INT. ELECTOR’S RESIDENCE.
Oh dear. I think we may have insulted our host.
Yes, that did seem to touch a nerve. No wonder she stormed out.
So what do we do now?
I’d still like to know more about this Chronoscope. Kartis might be a good person to ask.
The man we saw being convicted of murder?
If you want to hear the truth, ask somebody with nothing left to lose.
FX: DOOR OPENS. TEGAN ENTERS.
Tegan! How was your visit with Galen?
I need to talk to you, Doctor. In private.
Really? Well, if you think that’s necessary... Turlough, Nyssa. See if you can arrange an interview with Kartis before he’s transferred to the prison. I’1ll catch you up.
But —
Come on, Turlough. Let’s leave them to it.
Alright, I’11 do as I’m told.
FX: NYSSA AND TURLOUGH LEAVE. DOOR CLOSES BEHIND THEM.
Now. What did you want to speak to me about?
Doctor. The man I saw, Galen. He knows Nyssa.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 25
Sorry, what?
He’s a friend of hers, from after we left her on Terminus.
Ah. That could make things a little complicated.
That’s why he was wearing a mask, so she wouldn’t recognise him. Because he thinks the Nyssa we’re travelling with is from before we went to Terminus.
. Because she appears to be the same age now as she was then.

Right. And — give me a sec, because this is where it gets confusing — after Nyssa leaves us, he wants us to go to the planet Helheim, and save her. Because as far as he’s concerned, Nyssa never came back. He thinks she died there.
But she didn’t. That’s when we picked her up.
But he doesn’t know that! The point is, after Nyssa went missing in thirty-five thirty, she never returned to her own time.
Ah. I see.
Which means you never managed to take her back home again. Which means you never will!
Yes. By becoming part of the consequences of an event, we can no longer influence that event. Not without creating a paradox.
Or in other words, by bringing us here, you’ve prevented Nyssa from ever returning to her own time.
I didn’t bring us here. We were dragged off-course.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 26

The result’s the same, though, isn’t it? It’s now thirty-five fifty-six. Which means for twenty-five years, millions of people have been dying of Richter’s disease. People who’d still be alive if Nyssa had been able to return to thirty-five thirty with the cure!
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 13. INT. COURTHOUSE CELL.
FX: KARTIS IS SPEAKING VIA A MICROPHONE/SPEAKER, BEHIND GLASS.
DUNGEON ECHO.
I’d never kill anyone, I’m not a murderer. And if the Chronoscope lied about me, how many others has it lied about Since the ‘day of the miracle’?
But why send innocent people to prison?
As a reminder. If you can convince people that it’s futile to even think about breaking the law, they’1ll obey the people in charge.
FX: THE WATCHMAN IS WEARING A VOICE-MUFFLING BREATHING MASK,
LIKE A STORMTROOPER.
Time’s up. Prisoner is due to be transferred to the Alcazar.
Goodbye... Turlough — Nyssa.
Goodbye, Kartis.
FX: KARTIS IS TAKEN AWAY. DOOR OPENS. DOCTOR AND TEGAN RUSH IN.
There you are!
Tegan! Doctor —!
Change of plan. We have to go.
Go?
Leave. Get off this planet. Now.
Why?
Yes, Doctor. Why?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 28
It’s something to do with Galen, isn’t it? Something he told Tegan.
It’s none of your business.
For once, Tegan’s right, it really is none of your concern.
No? Because you don’t trust me. Wherever we go, it’s the same story. I’m kept in the dark about what’s really going on.
Turlough, this isn’t the time.
Then when is? When will I have proved myself to you?
For goodness’ sake. Of all the adolescent —
Adolescent? Alright, then — if you won’t tell me, I’1l go and ask Galen instead. (LEAVES)
(AS HE DEPARTS) Turlough, you’re being pathetic-!
Let him go, Tegan.
Aren’t you going to go after him?
Later. First we have to get you back to the TARDIS.
But why? Why is it so important that we should leave?
Please. Just this once, do as I say without asking questions!
The Doctor’s right. You have to get out of here.
FX: THEY EXIT.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 14. INT. LABORATORY
FX: DOOR OPENS, TURLOUGH ENTERS.
The chief physician is not to be disturbed —
I’‘’1ll only be a few moments. Ah. And I see that Galen no longer needs a mask.
It’s alright, Mahandra.
Very good.
FX: SHE LEAVES, CLOSING DOOR BEHIND HER.
There was no need to force your way in. If there’s something you wish to discuss —
There is. I want to know what you told Tegan.
Turlough, isn’t it? My mother mentioned you. You travelled together. Briefly.
Your mother?
Nyssa.
Sorry? Nyssa is your mother?
Yes. Or rather, she will be. That’s all in the future as far as she’s concerned. That’s why I was wearing the mask, to avoid creating a time paradox.
And that’s what you told Tegan?
I asked her to save Nyssa. Because twenty-five years ago, ona mission to the planet Helheim, my mother disappeared.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
(SURPRISED LAUGH) No she didn’t.
What?
After she left us, we bumped into her again. A few days later, or fifty years later, as far as she was concerned.
You're saying you’ve already been to Helheim?
You said she mentioned me to you. What did she say, exactly?
That she met you on Earth, at Brendon School, with a Brigadier, and a creature called Mawdryn. And that’s it.
She didn’t mention Purity? Or Vektris? Or the Sontarans?
No.
No. Because she had you in the fifty-year gap before we met her again.
But if the Nyssa with you is from after she went to Helheim, why does she look younger?
Because she was rejuvenated, by a substance called Hermogenite.
You mean my mother... who I thought had died, when I was fifteen years old... she’s been travelling with you all this time?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 31
SCENE 15. EXT. STREET.
FX: DOCTOR, TEGAN AND NYSSA MAKE THEIR WAY THROUGH THE TOWN.
LIVESTOCK CLUCKING AND SNORTING, TRADERS PACKING UP IN B/G.
This way, I think. Yes! Follow me!
FX: HE GOES ON AHEAD WITHOUT THEM, ALLOWING THEM TO TALK IN
PRIVATE.
Tegan. Will you please tell me why we have to leave?
(QUIET) You know how you wanted us to take you back to your own time, to thirty-five thirty?
Yes. So I could deliver the cure for Richter’s syndrome.
And return to your husband, and your children?
Tegan, you haven’t told the Doctor about them, have you?
No, don’t worry, I’ve been playing my cards close to my chest. But what if.. what if I told you, that you couldn’t go back and pick up your life from where you’d left off?
What are you saying?
The year is thirty-five fifty-six. We’re walking around in your future.
My future. And so the longer I remain here, the greater the chance of me finding out what happens to me...
FX: THE DOCTOR RETURNS.
Tegan, Nyssa — what are you waiting for?

DOCTOR: If you want to hear the truth, ask somebody with nothing left to lose.
DOCTOR: Tegan! How was your visit with Galen?
TEGAN: I need to talk to you, Doctor. In private.
DOCTOR: Really? Well, if you think that’s necessary... Turlough, Nyssa. See if you can arrange an interview with Kartis before he’s transferred to the prison. I’1ll catch you up.
TURLOUGH: But —
NYSSA: Come on, Turlough. Let’s leave them to it.
TURLOUGH: Alright, I’11 do as I’m told.
DOCTOR: Now. What did you want to speak to me about?
TEGAN: Doctor. The man I saw, Galen. He knows Nyssa.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 25
DOCTOR: Sorry, what?
TEGAN: He’s a friend of hers, from after we left her on Terminus.
DOCTOR: Ah. That could make things a little complicated.
TEGAN: That’s why he was wearing a mask, so she wouldn’t recognise him. Because he thinks the Nyssa we’re travelling with is from before we went to Terminus.
DOCTOR: . Because she appears to be the same age now as she was then.
TEGAN: Right. And — give me a sec, because this is where it gets confusing — after Nyssa leaves us, he wants us to go to the planet Helheim, and save her. Because as far as he’s concerned, Nyssa never came back. He thinks she died there.
DOCTOR: But she didn’t. That’s when we picked her up.
TEGAN: But he doesn’t know that! The point is, after Nyssa went missing in thirty-five thirty, she never returned to her own time.
DOCTOR: Ah. I see.
TEGAN: Which means you never managed to take her back home again. Which means you never will!
DOCTOR: Yes. By becoming part of the consequences of an event, we can no longer influence that event. Not without creating a paradox.
TEGAN: Or in other words, by bringing us here, you’ve prevented Nyssa from ever returning to her own time.
DOCTOR: I didn’t bring us here. We were dragged off-course.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 26
TEGAN: The result’s the same, though, isn’t it? It’s now thirty-five fifty-six. Which means for twenty-five years, millions of people have been dying of Richter’s disease. People who’d still be alive if Nyssa had been able to return to thirty-five thirty with the cure!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 27
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 13. INT. COURTHOUSE CELL.
DOCTOR WHO: DUNGEON ECHO.
KARTIS: I’d never kill anyone, I’m not a murderer. And if the Chronoscope lied about me, how many others has it lied about Since the ‘day of the miracle’?
NYSSA: But why send innocent people to prison?
TURLOUGH: As a reminder. If you can convince people that it’s futile to even think about breaking the law, they’1ll obey the people in charge.
TURLOUGH: LIKE A STORMTROOPER.
FIRST WATCHMAN: Time’s up. Prisoner is due to be transferred to the Alcazar.
KARTIS: Goodbye... Turlough — Nyssa.
NYSSA: Goodbye, Kartis.
TEGAN: There you are!
NYSSA: Tegan! Doctor —!
DOCTOR: Change of plan. We have to go.
TURLOUGH: Go?
DOCTOR: Leave. Get off this planet. Now.
TURLOUGH: Why?
NYSSA: Yes, Doctor. Why?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 28
TURLOUGH: It’s something to do with Galen, isn’t it? Something he told Tegan.
TEGAN: It’s none of your business.
DOCTOR: For once, Tegan’s right, it really is none of your concern.
TURLOUGH: No? Because you don’t trust me. Wherever we go, it’s the same story. I’m kept in the dark about what’s really going on.
DOCTOR: Turlough, this isn’t the time.
TURLOUGH: Then when is? When will I have proved myself to you?
TEGAN: For goodness’ sake. Of all the adolescent —
TURLOUGH: Adolescent? Alright, then — if you won’t tell me, I’1l go and ask Galen instead. (LEAVES)
TEGAN: (AS HE DEPARTS) Turlough, you’re being pathetic-!
DOCTOR: Let him go, Tegan.
NYSSA: Aren’t you going to go after him?
DOCTOR: Later. First we have to get you back to the TARDIS.
NYSSA: But why? Why is it so important that we should leave?
DOCTOR: Please. Just this once, do as I say without asking questions!
TEGAN: The Doctor’s right. You have to get out of here.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 29
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 14. INT. LABORATORY
MAHANDRA: The chief physician is not to be disturbed —
TURLOUGH: I’‘’1ll only be a few moments. Ah. And I see that Galen no longer needs a mask.
ADRIC: It’s alright, Mahandra.
MAHANDRA: Very good.
ADRIC: There was no need to force your way in. If there’s something you wish to discuss —
TURLOUGH: There is. I want to know what you told Tegan.
ADRIC: Turlough, isn’t it? My mother mentioned you. You travelled together. Briefly.
TURLOUGH: Your mother?
ADRIC: Nyssa.
TURLOUGH: Sorry? Nyssa is your mother?
ADRIC: Yes. Or rather, she will be. That’s all in the future as far as she’s concerned. That’s why I was wearing the mask, to avoid creating a time paradox.
TURLOUGH: And that’s what you told Tegan?
ADRIC: I asked her to save Nyssa. Because twenty-five years ago, ona mission to the planet Helheim, my mother disappeared.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 30
TURLOUGH: (SURPRISED LAUGH) No she didn’t.
ADRIC: What?
TURLOUGH: After she left us, we bumped into her again. A few days later, or fifty years later, as far as she was concerned.
ADRIC: You're saying you’ve already been to Helheim?
TURLOUGH: You said she mentioned me to you. What did she say, exactly?
ADRIC: That she met you on Earth, at Brendon School, with a Brigadier, and a creature called Mawdryn. And that’s it.
TURLOUGH: She didn’t mention Purity? Or Vektris? Or the Sontarans?
ADRIC: No.
TURLOUGH: No. Because she had you in the fifty-year gap before we met her again.
ADRIC: But if the Nyssa with you is from after she went to Helheim, why does she look younger?
TURLOUGH: Because she was rejuvenated, by a substance called Hermogenite.
ADRIC: You mean my mother... who I thought had died, when I was fifteen years old... she’s been travelling with you all this time?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 15. EXT. STREET.
DOCTOR WHO: LIVESTOCK CLUCKING AND SNORTING, TRADERS PACKING UP IN B/G.
DOCTOR: This way, I think. Yes! Follow me!
DOCTOR: PRIVATE.
NYSSA: Tegan. Will you please tell me why we have to leave?
TEGAN: (QUIET) You know how you wanted us to take you back to your own time, to thirty-five thirty?
NYSSA: Yes. So I could deliver the cure for Richter’s syndrome.
TEGAN: And return to your husband, and your children?
NYSSA: Tegan, you haven’t told the Doctor about them, have you?
TEGAN: No, don’t worry, I’ve been playing my cards close to my chest. But what if.. what if I told you, that you couldn’t go back and pick up your life from where you’d left off?
NYSSA: What are you saying?
TEGAN: The year is thirty-five fifty-six. We’re walking around in your future.
NYSSA: My future. And so the longer I remain here, the greater the chance of me finding out what happens to me...
DOCTOR: Tegan, Nyssa — what are you waiting for?
NYSSA: Doctor. Tegan’s told me. About why we have to leave.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 32
DOCTOR: (FEARING THE WORST) She has?
NYSSA: Because by being here I risk discovering something about my own
NYSSA: future.
DOCTOR: Ah. Yes.
NYSSA: You’re right. I should leave. I don’t know why you couldn’t just tell me.
DOCTOR: Because it was important I got you back to the TARDIS, before —
MAHANDRA: Halt. Do not move.
DOCTOR: - before this.
TEGAN: Mahandra, right? What’s with the handgun?
MAHANDRA: Chief physician Galen wishes to speak to you.
TEGAN: (BEMUSED) He’s already spoken to me.
MAHANDRA: Not to you. To Nyssa.
NYSSA: Why?
MAHANDRA: He will answer that. You will all come with me. Now!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 33
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 16. EXT. OUTSIDE LABORATORY.
DOCTOR WHO: RATTLING METAL STAIRS TO THE BALCONY OUTSIDE OF THE LABORATORY; OPEN TO THE ELEMENTS.
MAHANDRA: Wait here.
ADRIC: (MASKED) Doctor, Nyssa. Tegan. How pleasant to make your re- acquaintance.
DOCTOR: Well, we’re very pleasant company. I see you’ve been speaking to Turlough.
TURLOUGH: (GUILTY) Doctor, I didn’t realise. You should’ve told me —
DOCTOR: Told you what?
ADRIC: (MASKED) Nyssa, if you would care to step inside with Mahandra...
NYSSA: If you insist.
DOCTOR: Galen. Listen to me. I know you’re an acquaintance of Nyssa’s, from her future.
ADRIC: (MASKED) An acquaintance? Is that what you told him, Tegan?
TEGAN: ‘Friend’ seemed to be over-doing it.
DOCTOR: You have to understand, Nyssa must not find out about anything that happens to her after she leaves us. If she does, it could result in a time paradox.
ADRIC: (MASKED) Oh, don’t lie to me, Doctor.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 34
DOCTOR: What?
ADRIC: (MASKED) Turlough’s already told me. About how you rescued Nyssa from Helheim.
TEGAN: (FURIOUS) Turlough told you?-?!
TURLOUGH: I didn’t realise it was meant to be a secret!
DOCTOR: It doesn’t make any difference. You still can’t tell Nyssa about her own future.
ADRIC: (MASKED) And how could I do that? I have no idea what will
ADRIC: happen to her. All I know is that she never came home.
DOCTOR: Galen, please-!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 35
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 17. INT. LABORATORY (CONTINUOUS )
ADRIC: (MASKED) Mahandra, if you could keep an eye on the others outside? I don’t want any interruptions.
MAHANDRA: As you wish.
NYSSA: Why did you have her bring me here?
ADRIC: (MASKED) Because I wished for you — (REMOVES MASK) — for you to see my face. (BEAT) Well? Don’t you recognise me?
NYSSA: (SHE DOES, BUT PRETENDS SHE DOESN’T) No, no I don’t. I’ve never seen you before in my life.
ADRIC: Mother, it’s me. Twenty-five years older than when you last saw me. I’m Adric. Your son!
NYSSA: (LYING) I... I don’t have a son.
ADRIC: Mother, please-!
NYSSA: Please, I’m only twenty years old. If you’re from my future then I can’t know about it!
ADRIC: Mother, you don’t have to pretend. Your friend Turlough told me that you were made young again. Younger than I remember you. Younger than your own son.
NYSSA: (OVERCOME) My own son... Adric!
ADRIC: My mother. Back from the dead.
NYSSA: What?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 36
ADRIC: We all thought you’d died, when you never returned from your mission to Helheim.
NYSSA: I never came back?
ADRIC: No. The last time I saw you was when you kissed me goodbye.
NYSSA: I’m so sorry. I meant to come back. Truly, I did!
ADRIC: (ANGRY) Then why didn’t you? What was more important to you than me? Than Neeka? What was more important than your own son, crying himself to sleep, night after night?
NYSSA: I never meant for it to be like this. If I could go back to that time, I would, but...
ADRIC: But what?
NYSSA: . but now that I’ve met you here, I can’t, can I? I can’t!
ADRIC: You let me think you were dead! For twenty-five years!
NYSSA: Don’t you think I’d do anything, anything, to put things right, to get those years back? To go back to thirty-five thirty with the cure for Richter’s —
ADRIC: (SHARPLY) What did you say? You found a cure?
NYSSA: (MISERABLE) Yes.
ADRIC: And still you never came back? (APPALLED) Mother - do you have any idea how many people have died of Richter’s in the last twenty-five years? Do you have any idea of the suffering its caused? To people like Neeka?
NYSSA: My daughter. Oh no, no —
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 37
ADRIC: Don’t worry. She’s still alive. In suspended animation on Maxis Realtor. She became infected while treating the sick.
NYSSA: And your father? Where’s he? Where’s Lasarti?
ADRIC: He died. Ten years ago. He died alone.
NYSSA: I’m sorry, Adric. What more can I say? I’m sorry. I’m sorry. I’m sorry!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 38
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 18. EXT. OUTSIDE LABORATORY.
TURLOUGH: I think we can assume that he’s telling her everything.
DOCTOR: Yes. I don’t suppose she will ever forgive me.
MAHANDRA: Sibor? What are you-
SIBOR: There they are. Watchmen! Arrest the woman Tegan and the man Turlough.
FIRST WATCHMAN: Yes, ma’am.
FIRST WATCHMAN: APPREHEND THEM, COCKING MACHINE GUNS.
TEGAN: Arrest us? What for?
TURLOUGH: We’ve done nothing wrong!
SIBOR: Not yet. But the Chronoscope has just made a prediction. It has shown the pair of you committing cold-blooded murder.
TEGAN: But that’s ridiculous!
TURLOUGH: Who would we want to murder?
SIBOR: One of my Watchmen, whilst attempting to make your escape.
DOCTOR: And the Chronoscope is never wrong...!
DOCTOR: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 39

elements.text: PART TWO
NO REPRISE
SCENE 19. INT. LABORATORY.

After you disappeared, we left Zarat and never stayed on the same planet for more than a few months. Father buried himself in his work and I enrolled at the college on Triesto, got a first class degree in xeno-medicine, and specialised in the treatment of Richter’s. To help people, and honour your memory.
And Neeka?

She became a medic. She’d go to the pariah worlds and tend to the sick even as the cities were being overrun. She saw whole populations reduced to blood-thirsty savages. In the end, she became infected, a microscopic tear in her hazard suit. She was thirty-five when it happened. My older sister and she’s younger than me now.
And all this time, you’ve been working to find a cure.
Why else do you think I came to Valderon? To further my research I needed experimental subjects. And this was the only world with a ready supply of... volunteers.
Volunteers? (REALISES) This is a penal colony!
The prisoners can either help me with my work, or remain in the Alcazar.
That’s not much of a choice. What exactly have you been doing to your ‘volunteers’?
Each subject is infected with Richter’s, then injected with an anti-viral compound, to evaluate its efficacy at delaying the progress of the disease.
And then what happens to them?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 40
They’re placed in cryogen storage.
Still infected with Richter’s!
Does it matter? I had to find a cure somehow! And I was on the right track, I’m sure of it!
You’re just like your father. Never give up.
You don’t understand. I know I would’ve found a cure because the Chronoscope predicted it.
Except it wasn’t you that found it. It was me. That’s what the Chronoscope predicted.
At least I was trying to find a cure — rather than travelling the galaxy with the Doctor having already found it.
I meant to come back, Adric, but travelling with the Doctor, things have a tendency to get in the way.
That’s your excuse, is it?
An explanation. I can’t undo the past. Much as I would wish to.
So what is it? The cure?
It’s an adapted form of the antigen of a creature called a Cractid. I have a sample in the TARDIS.
Then you’d better fetch it, hadn’t you?
Adric, it’s not as simple as that! I developed a vaccine, yes, but it soon became unstable — because the virus itself is constantly mutating.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 41
Which means it evolves a resistance to any vaccine. I know.
So the only solution is to augment the vaccine with a counter- mutation that will match and predict the mutation of the virus.
I see...
But to do that, I would need a detailed analysis of the virus’s mutative pattern.
But.. I have that data. I’ve charted all of Richter’s mutations over twenty-five years across seven galaxies!
Then that means — all we have to do is augment my anti-viral solution with a counter-mutation based on your data!
Once we’ve done that, I can broadcast the formula to the affected colonies — and we can wipe out Richter’s for good!
Let’s get started, then, [shall we?]
FX: SHE’S INTERRUPTED BY THE DOOR OPENING. MAHANDRA ENTERS.
Mahandra! I told you we were not to be disturbed.
I’m sorry, but it’s Tegan and Turlough. Prime Elector Sibor has had them arrested.
Arrested? What for?
Premeditation to murder. It seems the Chronoscope predicted them killing one of the watchmen.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 42
SCENE 20. INT. COURTROOM
FX: FADE UP. HUBBUB OF PUBLIC GALLERY DIES DOWN.
Vislor Turlough, Tegan Jovanka. You stand indicted of premeditation to murder. Do you understand the nature of the charge?
Only too well.
And you, Tegan?
I think you’ve all gone barmy.
My, ah, client wishes to express her reservations as to the verity of the prediction.
Then your ‘client’ will see for herself. Replay the prediction.
FX: RECORDING BEGINS TO PLAY. A SNEAK PREVIEW OF SCENE 72.
Alright, you two. Come out of there with your hands up.
No. You drop your gun and put your hands up. Or I’1l fire.
Put the gun down, lad.
No. You put yours down. I’ll count to three. One. Two. Three.
FX: GUN FIRES.
BRIEF GASP
FX: WATCHMAN COLLAPSES, DEAD.
Turlough... You killed him!
FX: RECORDING ENDS. PUBLIC GALLERY ALARMED.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 43
The prediction is clear. Had you not been detained you would have committed murder.
Objection! The evidence of the Chronoscope is unreliable.
The accuracy of the Chronoscope is beyond reproach.
Is it? Everything it predicts has to happen, exactly as depicted?
Yes.
But the recording it’s just shown us, that’s not going to happen, is it?
Not now, no, but —
. but that’s the point, isn’t it? You say the Chronoscope is reliable, but every time it predicts a crime which then never takes place its prediction is one-hundred-per-cent wrong!
The crime would have taken place, had it not been prevented.
You have no way of proving that! The whole notion is inherently paradoxical! This gadget of yours might be handy for weather forecasts but you can’t use it as the basis of a judicial system!
This defence is inadmissible!
You have no direct evidence, no motive, no case. For goodness’ sake, it didn’t even sound like them!
Turlough and Tegan. You are hereby declared guilty of premeditation to murder. You are to be detained in the Alcazar for the remainder of both your natural lives.
FX: TEGAN AND TURLOUGH ARE DRAGGED AWAY.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 44
But we’re innocent. We haven’t done anything!
And we weren’t going to!
FX: TEGAN AND TURLOUGH REMOVED FROM COURTROOM. FADE.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 45
SCENE 21. INT. ELECTOR’S RESIDENCE.
FX: DOOR OPENS. NYSSA ENTERS. DOOR CLOSES BEHIND.
Doctor. I only just heard, about Tegan and Turlough.
Yes. I’ve just been defending them in court. I’m afraid I didn’t do a terribly good job.
They were found guilty?
Yes. They’re being transferred to the Alcazar as we speak.
Doctor. Galen told me. That I never returned to thirty-five thirty.
Ah. Nyssa, I’m so sorry.
That’s why you wanted us to leave. You didn’t want me to find out.
I didn’t see what good it would do.
Don’t you think I had a right to know? That I could never return to my own time?
Because of me. I should’ve taken you back straight away, instead of dragging you off around the universe.
No, Doctor. That was my choice. If anyone’s to blame, then it’s me. And believe me, I could not be more furious with myself for what’s happened.
It’s not your fault.
Yes it is. But I’m angry at you, for trying to keep this from me.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 46
You’re right. I was being selfish, inconsiderate. I thought —
What?
I thought that knowing might be too much for you to bear.
I’ve lost my parents, my world, I’ve lost... I’ve lost so many people dear to me, and you thought it might be too much for me to bear? I thought I could trust you, Doctor. But it appears I was wrong.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 47
SCENE 22. INT. CELL.
FX: ELECTRONIC DOOR SLIDES SHUT WITH A CLANG. LOW-TECH, BADLY-
MAINTAINED. CELL IS ESSENTIALLY A DUNGEON; STONE WALLS, FLOOR. DRIPPING. DISTANT PIPES OCCASIONALLY GURGLE AND CLANK.
(QUIETLY MUMBLING IN HIS SLEEP IN B/G THROUGHOUT SCENE, NOT ALWAYS DECIPHERABLE) No... I won’t.. Leave me alone.. I won’t do it.. No.. what are you... go away... I can’t... what do you want... (ETC)
Fantastic. Locked up. As usual!
It seems we have a cell-mate. Maintenance Engineer Kartis.
What sort of a place is this where they lock a single woman up with two men?
One where they are keeping a constant eye on us via a security camera.
Makes sense, I suppose. But I’d prefer some privacy.
MORE AGITATED MOANING
Sounds like he’s having a nightmare.
(SHAKING) Kartis. Kartis. Wake up!
(WAKING) What... Turlough, what are you doing here?
Same as you. Framed by the Chronoscope.
And who’s [this] —?
Tegan. A friend.
Sounds like you were having quite the bad dream.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 48
They say that this place gets inside your head. Makes you walk in your sleep. Makes you do things — hurt yourself, or others.
Then the sooner we get out of here, the better.
Any suggestions? I notice a distinct lack of ventilation ducts, and these walls are solid stone!
I’1l think of something, Turlough, don’t you worry.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 49
SCENE 23. INT. LABORATORY
FX: MAHANDRA WHEELS IN A SILENT PATIENT.
This is the most recent experimental subject. As he’d only just been placed in suspended animation, he should be the fastest to revive.
What do you intend to do with this man, Galen?
We still have to test the modified anti-viral.
The Richter’s virus is constantly changing, but A- (STOPS HERSELF BECAUSE DOCTOR IS PRESENT) — but Galen has datasets
that accurately predict how that mutation will occur. Doctor — we could wipe it out in all its forms forever!
If it works.
Beginning the re-animation process now.
FX: GADGET BLEEPS, LOW HUMMING, LIKE A MICROWAVE ON ‘DEFROST’.
(EMPHASIZE HE’S NOT SAYING ‘MOTHER’) Nyssa — have you finished
encoding the sample of the anti-viral?
Yes, Galen. Here.
(TAKING IT) Thank you.
BEGINS TO WAKE, BREATHING, AGITATED
The subject is regaining consciousness.
FX: MICROWAVE HUM OFF.
Proceed with injection of anti-viral solution.
Injecting... now.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 50
FX: GADGET BLEEPS.
How long till we know if it’s worked?
A few minutes.
NYSSA’S VOICE: (WITHIN HER MIND, SAPPHIRE & STEEL EFFECT — A FAINT, SINISTER, SIBILANT VOICE WHISPERING CLOSE TO MIC) Nyssa.
(PAINED) Doctor... I...
Nyssa. What is it? Are you alright?
I.. I’m not sure. I thought I heard something. Whispering my name.
Like the prisoners.
What?
The inmates of the Alcazar exhibit an abnormally high rate of psychological problems. One of the first symptoms is the belief they can hear voices.
A schizophrenic disorder.
Perhaps, but I doubt it. Nyssa is unusually sensitive. Given the right conditions, that sensitivity borders on telepathy. Nyssa. Can you describe what you heard?
It was my own voice. But it was as if a presence was reaching into my mind.
A ‘presence’ ?
An extremely powerful one, I should imagine.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 51
Doctor. Do you think it might have something to do with whatever brought us here?
It’s a distinct possibility.
If the effect is most pronounced on the inmates of the prison... might that be its point of origin?
My thoughts exactly. Nyssa, it’s time we paid Tegan and Turlough a visit.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 52
SCENE 24. INT. CELL.
FX: LIGHTS FIZZ AND CLUNK AS THEY ARE SWITCHED TO NEW SETTING.
They’re switching off the lights. Must be getting late. Turlough, are you alright?
Just a headache. Throbbing. Would you mind if I took the other bed?
Be my guest.
That’s how it begins. First a headache, then voices, and then madness. You should put yourself forward for one of the chief physician’s experiments. That’s the only way out of here.
You’re a laugh a minute, aren’t you?
FX: TURLOUGH TAKES THE BED.
(PAINED, WEAK) It would help if you didn’t argue.
It’s alright, Turlough. You just get some rest.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 53
SCENE 25. INT. LABORATORY
FX: GADGET BLEEPS.
Anti-viral compound proved... effective. It worked!
Are you sure? Absolutely sure?
All the disease markers are negative. There’s not a trace of infection.
FX: DOOR OPENS. SIBOR ENTERS, ESCORTED BY WATCHMEN.
Sibor! Just the person. We’ve done it. We’ve found a cure for Richter’s!
I know. The Chronoscope predicted as such.
It did?
That’s why I’m here. Watchmen. Restrain Adric and his assistant.
Yes, ma’am.
FX: WATCHMEN GRAB ADRIC AND MAHANDRA.
What are you doing?
Don’t you understand, we’ve found the cure —
Which is why I’m going to have you confined to the Alcazar. To make sure you don’t do anything... foolish.
Sibor, what are you playing at?
Adric. Why do you think I permitted you to come here? Why do you think I went to such lengths to support your research?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 54
I assumed it was because you wanted to save lives.

There’s nobody infected with Richter’s on Valderon. Since the plague began, we’ve flourished in glorious isolation. No. I wanted you to find a cure to give us something to use as leverage against the empire.
Leverage? You intend to hold the empire to ransom?
Either they recognise me as the new Prime Elector, or they can watch all their citizens die slowly, violently and painfully.
It’ll never work. They’1ll never accept your terms.
On the contrary. The Chronoscope has already foreseen that they will.
(SLURRING, WAKING UP) What — where am I —
I’d watch out if I was you. That patient is still infected with Richter’s.

Heiu qua nes mes tirume eine halbe miljoen pertsonak habitabat in shanty oppida poza hofuoborg et deu scias kiom da nan yo ki infecte.

ADRIC/NYSSA VOICES: (INSIDE THEIR MINDS)

FX: ALIEN PULSING, RUMBLING SOUND HAS INCREASED, SO LOUD PEOPLE

ADRIC: After you disappeared, we left Zarat and never stayed on the same planet for more than a few months. Father buried himself in his work and I enrolled at the college on Triesto, got a first class degree in xeno-medicine, and specialised in the treatment of Richter’s. To help people, and honour your memory.
NYSSA: And Neeka?
ADRIC: She became a medic. She’d go to the pariah worlds and tend to the sick even as the cities were being overrun. She saw whole populations reduced to blood-thirsty savages. In the end, she became infected, a microscopic tear in her hazard suit. She was thirty-five when it happened. My older sister and she’s younger than me now.
NYSSA: And all this time, you’ve been working to find a cure.
ADRIC: Why else do you think I came to Valderon? To further my research I needed experimental subjects. And this was the only world with a ready supply of... volunteers.
NYSSA: Volunteers? (REALISES) This is a penal colony!
ADRIC: The prisoners can either help me with my work, or remain in the Alcazar.
NYSSA: That’s not much of a choice. What exactly have you been doing to your ‘volunteers’?
ADRIC: Each subject is infected with Richter’s, then injected with an anti-viral compound, to evaluate its efficacy at delaying the progress of the disease.
NYSSA: And then what happens to them?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 40
ADRIC: They’re placed in cryogen storage.
NYSSA: Still infected with Richter’s!
ADRIC: Does it matter? I had to find a cure somehow! And I was on the right track, I’m sure of it!
NYSSA: You’re just like your father. Never give up.
ADRIC: You don’t understand. I know I would’ve found a cure because the Chronoscope predicted it.
NYSSA: Except it wasn’t you that found it. It was me. That’s what the Chronoscope predicted.
ADRIC: At least I was trying to find a cure — rather than travelling the galaxy with the Doctor having already found it.
NYSSA: I meant to come back, Adric, but travelling with the Doctor, things have a tendency to get in the way.
ADRIC: That’s your excuse, is it?
NYSSA: An explanation. I can’t undo the past. Much as I would wish to.
ADRIC: So what is it? The cure?
NYSSA: It’s an adapted form of the antigen of a creature called a Cractid. I have a sample in the TARDIS.
ADRIC: Then you’d better fetch it, hadn’t you?
NYSSA: Adric, it’s not as simple as that! I developed a vaccine, yes, but it soon became unstable — because the virus itself is constantly mutating.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 41
ADRIC: Which means it evolves a resistance to any vaccine. I know.
NYSSA: So the only solution is to augment the vaccine with a counter- mutation that will match and predict the mutation of the virus.
ADRIC: I see...
NYSSA: But to do that, I would need a detailed analysis of the virus’s mutative pattern.
ADRIC: But.. I have that data. I’ve charted all of Richter’s mutations over twenty-five years across seven galaxies!
NYSSA: Then that means — all we have to do is augment my anti-viral solution with a counter-mutation based on your data!
ADRIC: Once we’ve done that, I can broadcast the formula to the affected colonies — and we can wipe out Richter’s for good!
NYSSA: Let’s get started, then, [shall we?]
ADRIC: Mahandra! I told you we were not to be disturbed.
MAHANDRA: I’m sorry, but it’s Tegan and Turlough. Prime Elector Sibor has had them arrested.
NYSSA: Arrested? What for?
MAHANDRA: Premeditation to murder. It seems the Chronoscope predicted them killing one of the watchmen.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 42
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 20. INT. COURTROOM
SIBOR: Vislor Turlough, Tegan Jovanka. You stand indicted of premeditation to murder. Do you understand the nature of the charge?
TURLOUGH: Only too well.
SIBOR: And you, Tegan?
TEGAN: I think you’ve all gone barmy.
DOCTOR: My, ah, client wishes to express her reservations as to the verity of the prediction.
SIBOR: Then your ‘client’ will see for herself. Replay the prediction.
FIRST WATCHMAN: Alright, you two. Come out of there with your hands up.
TURLOUGH: No. You drop your gun and put your hands up. Or I’1l fire.
FIRST WATCHMAN: Put the gun down, lad.
TURLOUGH: No. You put yours down. I’ll count to three. One. Two. Three.
TEGAN: Turlough... You killed him!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 43
SIBOR: The prediction is clear. Had you not been detained you would have committed murder.
DOCTOR: Objection! The evidence of the Chronoscope is unreliable.
SIBOR: The accuracy of the Chronoscope is beyond reproach.
DOCTOR: Is it? Everything it predicts has to happen, exactly as depicted?
SIBOR: Yes.
DOCTOR: But the recording it’s just shown us, that’s not going to happen, is it?
SIBOR: Not now, no, but —
DOCTOR: . but that’s the point, isn’t it? You say the Chronoscope is reliable, but every time it predicts a crime which then never takes place its prediction is one-hundred-per-cent wrong!
SIBOR: The crime would have taken place, had it not been prevented.

SIBOR: A matter of security. Only I may make contact with the rest of the empire — and only when I... (SUDDEN GASP OF PAIN, CONTINUES)
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page
ADRIC: What’s happening —
NYSSA: Can’t you feel it? The presence I felt earlier...
ADRIC: Yes...
ADRIC: ADRIC/NYSSA VOICES: (INSIDE THEIR MINDS)
ADRIC: INCREASING INTENSITY, THE ALIEN SOUND HEARD IN SCENE 36.
ADRIC: It’s inside my mind. I can’t think!
NYSSA: It’s stronger... and getting stronger all the time.
NYSSA: We have to fight it...
ADRIC: I can’t... too strong... (GASP OF PAIN)
NYSSA: Adric. (IN INCREASING PAIN) No. No... please... stop. Stop!
NYSSA: 78
NYSSA: Stop!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 79
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 40. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER.
DOCTOR WHO: NEED TO BE TALKING (NOT SHOUTING) OVER IT. SINISTER WHISPERING CONTINUES.
DOCTOR: Mahandra, Kartis. Keep back! Leave this to me.
MAHANDRA: Doctor. It hurts... feels like my brain’s in a vice...
DOCTOR: Turlough, Tegan! Get away from that thing now!
TEGAN: (DREAMLIKE) Doctor...
TURLOUGH: (DREAMLIKE) .. You’re here.
KARTIS: What is it?
DOCTOR: That? That’s your ‘Chronoscope’. (REALIZES) Oh no. It can’t be. It’s not possible.
DOCTOR: TALK WITH SOME SLIGHT VOICE EFFECT, TEGAN WITHOUT AUSTRALIAN ACCENT.
TEGAN: (POSSESSED) Not possible?
TURLOUGH: (POSSESSED) Surely you should know better than that.
DOCTOR: I should have realised. Telepathic influence, the ability to see into the future, to translate any language. Mahandra, Kartis. You have to leave now. You’re in terrible danger!
KARTIS: Why? What’s going on?
DOCTOR: I was wrong. It’s not a Time Lord. That white cabinet is a TARDIS.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page
TEGAN: (POSSESSED) And not just any TARDIS, Doctor.
TURLOUGH: (POSSESSED) Don’t you remember me?
DOCTOR: Remember you?
TEGAN: (POSSESSED) I’m your TARDIS.
TURLOUGH: (POSSESSED) Your first TARDIS.
TURLOUGH: END OF PART TWO
TURLOUGH: 80
