elements.text: PART THREE
REPRISE:
I was wrong. It’s not a Time Lord. That white cabinet is a
TARDIS.
And not just any TARDIS, Doctor.
Don’t you remember me?
Remember you?
I’m your TARDIS.
Your first TARDIS.
SCENE 41. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER [CONTINUED]
(NB: POSSESSED TEGAN WITH VOICE EFFECT IS NAMED ‘TEGAN TARDIS’ FROM NOW ON; DITTO TURLOUGH AND LATER SIBOR)
I don’t believe it. My old type fifty!
So you do remember!
But you shouldn’t be here. You should be on Gallifrey.
Where you left me?
Where you abandoned me?
Doctor, what is this ‘type fifty’?
An... acquaintance of mine. From my youth.
Doctor... my head. (GROANS IN PAIN)
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 82
FX: MAHANDRA STAGGERS.
Kartis, you have to get Mahandra out of here. The TARDIS is generating an extremely powerful telepathic field.
T=
The longer you’re exposed, the greater the risk of permanent
injury.
What about Tegan and Turlough?
I’1ll worry about them. Go!
Come on, Mahandra.
MUMBLING
FX: KARTIS AND MAHANDRA LEAVE.
So, Doctor. I have you all to myself. At last.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 83
SCENE 42. INT. COMMUNICATIONS CENTRE.
Mother? Mother, are you alright?
(WAKING) I think so. What happened?
I’m not sure. It was like being engulfed by a tidal wave.
FX: NYSSA PULLS HERSELF TO HER FEET. BRIEF BURST OF EERIE
WHISPERING.
The presence I felt, it’s growing stronger. (REALIZES) Sibor and her watchmen, they’ve gone!
For all the good it does us. With the communications unit out of action, there’s nothing we can do.
There is one thing we can do.
What?
Repair it.
But that’1ll take hours.
Then I suggest we get started.
FX: SHE STARTS MOVING EQUIPMENT.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 84
SCENE 43. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER
FX: TYPE FIFTY’S THROB OF POWER HAS SUBSIDED. EVER-PRESENT, BUT
QUIETER.
Now. Release Tegan and Turlough.
But then how would I be able to speak to you?
Don’t worry, Doctor. They will come to no harm.
From looking into their memories, I see they are valuable to you.
Very well. Then tell me. What are you doing here?
Looking for you.
What?
After you left Gallifrey. After you spurned me.
Taking another in my place.
It wasn’t like that... There wasn’t time to pick and choose, I had to take the first TARDIS I could lay my hands on!
FX: TYPE-FIFTY’S THROBBING SUDDENLY INCREASES IN INTENSITY.
TURLOUGH TARDIS & TEGAN TARDIS: (TOGETHER) You should have taken me!
FX: THROBBING SUBSIDES.
Believe me, if I could, I would.
But instead you chose another.
A miserable, dilapidated, obsolete type forty.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 85
Without even a functioning navigational circuit.
Without even a functioning chameleon circuit!
Oh, I don’t know. I’ve rather got used to it. And besides, I see your chameleon circuit isn’t working too well either.
I sustained damage.
Damage?
While making my escape.
Escape? But for a TARDIS to leave Gallifrey of its own accord, it’s unheard of. Impossible.
Not quite. I broke free of my dimensional stabilizers.
Burned away my recall circuits. Jettisoned nine-tenths of my internal architecture.
And ripped through the Time Lords’ transduction barrier.
The quantum force field scorching at my skin.
My components warping and fusing...
Until, at last, I was free!
And then you tried to follow me?
I tried. But in the heat of my escape, my own navigational circuits had been vaporized.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 86
All I could do was materialize before my dematerialisation circuit was reduced to a charred cinder.
So you crash-landed here. Twenty years ago.
Crippled, broken and alone. Unable to dematerialize. Unable even to self-repair.
Only my telepathic circuits remained. And so I reached out, to the creatures of this world.
“The day of the miracle”. You gave everyone on the planet the gift of tongues.
I needed help. I needed power to restore myself!
But instead I was discovered by the woman, Sibor.
Let me guess. She didn’t exactly want to nurse you back to health.
I linked my mind with hers.
I showed her the future.
And when she realised what you could do, she decided to use you for her own political gain.
She imprisoned me. Tortured me. Only providing me with enough power to keep me alive, nothing else.
For twenty years, Doctor, I have been in pain.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 87
SCENE 44. INT. COMMUNICATIONS CENTRE
FX: ADRIC AND NYSSA WORKING ON COMMUNICATIONS UNIT.
If I can replace the destroyed circuits, I might be able to jury-rig a basic link.
Enough to transmit the formula?
No. But enough to call for help.
You’ve grown into a remarkable man, Adric. I just wish I hadn’t missed so much of it.
Yes, well, it’s too late to do anything about it now.
It was too late the moment I stepped out of the TARDTG...
FX: MONITOR FIZZES INTO LIFE.
Have you done it?
No, just reactivated the security network. It should help us keep a look-out, if nothing else.
Look there, the colonists — they’re all heading to the Alcazar. Like an army of sleepwalkers!
Including Sibor and the watchmen.
(REALISES) The Doctor was wrong!
What?
He thought my innate telepathic sensitivity would make me more susceptible. But what if it meant I was less susceptible?
That would explain why you haven’t been affected — (I suppose)
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 88
And why you haven’t been affected either, because you’re my son! Adric. Do you need my help to finish the repairs?
Not particularly, why —
Whatever’s inside that prison is becoming more and more
powerful. I must warn the Doctor.
FX: SHE LEAVES.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 89
SCENE 45. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER.
So you became Sibor’s Chronoscope, granting her sneak previews of the future.
But only showing her what I wanted her to see.
I thought so. Selecting potential futures to influence her behaviour. But why accuse innocent people?
To have them brought here, of course.
Of course. You’ve been trying to find somebody predisposed to mental domination. Somebody you could control!
For twenty years I had searched in vain.
Until you brought me two suitable subjects.

Yes. Being taken over by Eldrad must have weakened Turlough’s psychic defences, and the Mara left Tegan vulnerable, too. But my arrival was hardly a coincidence, was it? I presume that was your doing?
It took all of my reserves of strength.
One TARDIS calling out to another across the void.
And then you made them hook you up to the prison’s power
supply.
To enable the restoration of my circuits. Those that can be restored.
But without a dematerialisation circuit, you’re stuck here, no matter how much power you have.
Which is why I brought you here, Doctor.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 90
The one person I could trust in all the universe.
Flattery will get you nowhere. What do you want me to do?
Take me home. I want to go home.
Will you do that for me, Doctor? For your former TARDIS?
That’s all you ask?
That is all I desire.
Then I agree. If you release my friends first.
FX: ELECTRONIC WARPING EFFECT. TEGAN STAGGERS.
(BACK AS HERSELF) What the... what happened? Doctor?
Tegan. What’s the last thing you remember?
I remember Turlough was messing about with a power cable and — oh no, he’s still away with the fairies, isn’t he?
I asked you release both my friends.
As a testament of my good faith...
FX: ELECTRONIC WARPING EFFECT.
Doctor? Where... where am I?
In prison. You went walkabout during the night. Now, Doctor, would you mind telling us what the hell is going on?
You were both being mentally dominated. By that.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 91
The white cabinet?
A TARDIS. My former TARDIS, to be precise. My old type-fifty.
FX: HE PATS THE SIDE.
So why did it bring us here?
Because it wants me to take it home. And I’ve agreed.
You’re helping it? After what it did to us?
I feel a certain... obligation. Tegan, I need you to find Nyssa, and take her back to the TARDIS.
Whatever you say. Anything to get out of this dump.
FX: TEGAN LEAVES.
What about me?
I need your assistance with this. (PULLING OUT CABLES) At the moment this TARDIS is channelling vast amounts of energy, allowing it to extend its telepathic influence.
So?
So if you could take this end of the cable —
FX: TURLOUGH TAKES THE CABLE.
- and pull when I give the word, we can cut it off completely! Pull!
FX: TURLOUGH PULLS THE CABLE. BRIEF CRACKLING FIZZLE, LIKE AND
A CHANGE IN THE PULSE OF THE TARDIS, DROPPING PITCH, QUIETER.
But why disconnect its power supply? I thought you said you were going to help it.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 92
I am. But that doesn’t mean I have to trust it.
FX: DOCTOR WORKS ON REMOVING MORE CABLES.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 93
SCENE 46. INT. LIFT.
FX: LIFT DESCENDING.
Come on, come on!
FX: LIFT HALTS, DOOR OPENS. TEGAN EMERGES, DOOR CLOSES, LIFT
GOES UP.
At last. Though how I’m supposed to find my way out, I don’t know.
FX: KARTIS AND MAHANDRA ARE IN THE DISTANCE.
(OFF) Tegan, is that you?
FX: THEY RUN UP TO TEGAN.
Kartis! And Mahandra. Are you alright?
I think so. Just have this terrible headache.
Tell me about it. Do either of you know the way out of here?
Yes. But what about the Doctor and Turlough?
I’1ll explain on the way. I’d rather not hang around, if it’s all the same to you!
FX: A DOOR OPENS (NOT LIFT OR CELL DOOR), SIBOR EMERGES.
(TALKING AS THOUGH IN A DREAM) I’m afraid that’s not going to be possible.
FX: HER GUN POWERS UP.
Sibor.
You have to listen to us. The thing that you think is the Chronoscope — it’s alive!
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 94
(DREAMLIKE) Of course it’s alive. Otherwise how would I be able to hear it talking to me?
It’s no good, it’s controlling her. Just like it did with Turlough.
(NORMAL) It’s not controlling me. I am the Chronoscope’s saviour, its protector, its master. And if you want to remain alive, you will do as I command!
What do you want us to do?
FX: LIFT CLANKS.
The lift is descending. Quickly. Into this cell!
Alright, no need to push!
FX: THEY ARE SHOVED INTO A CELL. SIBOR SLAMS THE DOOR SHUT.
(WHISPER) Don’t make a sound. Any of you!
FX: OUTSIDE, THE LIFT ARRIVES. THE DOCTOR AND TURLOUGH EMERGE.
So we get back to the TARDIS, and then what?
Now that I’ve cut the type-fifty’s power, it should no longer have any effect on the TARDIS’s navigational systems.
So you'll be able to land the TARDIS inside the prison?
Not just that. With any luck I’1l be able to materialize it around the type-fifty itself!
And dematerialize with it on board?
Next stop, Gallifrey!
FX: AT THE END OF THIS, THEY WALK AWAY. THE CELL DOOR OPENS.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 95
Alright, they’ve gone. Into the lift, all of you.
You don’t understand, the Doctor wants to help.
You heard what he said. He wants to take the Chronoscope away from us. And I don’t intend to allow that to happen.
FX: THEY ARE ALL IN LIFT. DOOR CLOSES. UP THEY GO.
You know, I’m beginning to get a bit sick of riding in this thing.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 96
SCENE 47. PRISON CORRIDOR
FX: UNLIKE BEFORE, ALL THE INMATES ARE SILENT. DOCTOR AND
TURLOUGH RUN AND SLOW DOWN.
(RUNNING) Doctor, look. (STOPS) The guards, they’re dead!
No. Unconscious. Side-effect of the type-fifty’s influence, I should think. But now it’s deactivated they’1l soon be waking up as right as rain, give or take a few sore heads.
Then we’d better get out of here before they do.
FX: THEY RESUME RUNNING APACE.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 97
SCENE 48. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER.
FX: LIFT HALTS, DOOR OPENS.
Out, all of you.
I assume you’ve come here to plug that thing back in, right?
Correct.
So what do you need us for?
The Chronoscope has gazed into the seeds of time. It has another fate reserved for you.
Oh, great. I knew it wouldn’t be anything good.
Mahandra, Kartis. Back against that wall.
FX: THEY MOVE, MAHANDRA STUMBLES.
(GASP, IN PAIN) Please... just let me go. It hurts...
Sibor. If you switch that thing back on, it’1ll kill us all!
Not me. It’s going to make me Prime Elector of the Earth Empire. It’s promised!
FX: SHE PLUGS A CRACKLING ELECTRICAL POWER CABLE INTO THE WHITE
BOX.
Power must be restored! It must be restored! (INSANE LAUGHTER)
FX: AS IN SCENE 36, A RISING, OMINOUS, SINISTER THROB OF ALIEN
POWER.
(SHOUTING, IN PAIN) For worship’s sake, Sibor, let go of the cable. Let go!
FX: SIBOR IS ROASTED ALIVE, RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK-STYLE.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 98
LAUGHTER TURNS TO SCREAMS OF PAIN
FX: SURGE OF POWER KILLS SIBOR.. AND A TARDIS DEMATERIALISATION
SOUND BEGINS.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 99
SCENE 49. INT. PRISON CORRIDOR.
FX: APPROACHING FOOTSTEPS RUNNING.
Doctor. Someone’s coming!
FX: THEY HALT.
Yes. It appears not everyone has been sent to sleep —
FX: FOOTSTEPS HALT — IT’S NYSSA, APPROACHING.
Doctor!
What are you doing here?
Looking for you. I had to tell you. The thing in here, it’s more powerful than you realise.
That ‘thing’ is a TARDIS. The Doctor’s former property.
What?
I’ll explain later. What do you mean, more powerful?
It was scrambling our communications. And then it possessed Sibor and her guards, and everyone else as far as I could see.
Except you?
Except me and — (STOPS HERSELF) Doctor. My telepathic sensitivity doesn’t make me more vulnerable. It makes me immune!
Interesting. We can discuss it on the way back to the TARDIS!
But what about Tegan? Isn’t she still locked up in here somewhere?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 100
Haven’t you seen her?
No. Should I have done?
But I told her to find you. She should have bumped into you, on the way out.
I haven’t seen her.
Doctor. There’s no other way she could have got out.
You’re right. Something must have happened to her. (EXASPERATED) I seem to spend half my life running around after that woman!
FX: AS HE SPEAKS, THE SINISTER WHISPERING RETURNS.
DOCTOR/TURLOUGH/NYSSA VOICES: (INSIDE THEIR MINDS)
SINISTER VOICES WHISPERING) Doctor, Turlough. Nyssa. (REPEAT
Doctor. Can you hear that?
The type-fifty. Someone must have plugged it back in again.
Then we don’t have any choice. We have to go back.
Marvellous.
FX: WHISPERS ABATE INTO BACKGROUND, AUDIBLE BUT QUIET.
Ah. Not you, Turlough. I think you should get out of here before you fall under its influence a second time.
I’m not going to argue. I’ve had quite enough of this place.
Find Galen. He’s in the communication centre, he may need your help.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 101
Galen? You mean your —
Yes, that’s right, my future acquaintance.
(NOT SURE WHY NYSSA IS COVERING) Alright. I’1l find Galen.
FX: TURLOUGH LEAVES.
You’re sure you want to come with me, Nyssa?
Of course. It will give you a chance to explain what’s going
on.
FX: THEY HEAD OFF.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 102
SCENE 49. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER.
FX: CHILLY NIGHT WIND THROUGH GAPS IN TOWER, BUT NO
CHRONOSCOPE/TYPE-FIFTY SOUNDS.
Tegan. Tegan? Are you alright?
(WAKING) I think so, just about. What about Mahandra?
She’s out cold, but unharmed, as far as I can tell. Sibor’s dead. Electrocuted.
FX: TEGAN PULLS HERSELF TO HER FEET.
The TARDIS. It’s gone!
You mean the white box?
It must’ve dematerialized.
Dematerialized? These TARDISes can do that? Vanish into thin air?
That’s kind of the whole point. And now it could be anywhere. I have to warn the Doctor. Kartis?
I’ll stay here, with Mahandra.
Suit yourself. But if that thing comes back, I don’t recommend hanging around.
FX: TEGAN GOES.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 103
SCENE 50. INT. PRISON CORRIDOR.
FX: DOCTOR AND NYSSA APPROACHING.
So why didn’t you take the type-fifty, when you left Gallifrey?
Let’s just say, I was in rather a hurry.
And it left Gallifrey to search for you?
Yes. All TARDISes are sentient, after a fashion. They have a symbiotic link with their most favoured pilot... A kind of imprimatur. I never thought it would come after me, though.
The ‘symbiotic link’ must have been stronger than you realised.
With a little old-fashioned jealousy added into the mix. It resents the fact that I left in another TARDIS. An inferior model!
And now it wants you to take it home to be repaired?
So it claimed... Here we are. The elevator to the central tower, where Sibor’s been keeping it prisoner.
FX: THE LIFT IS DESCENDING.
It’s descending.
Yes. And I didn’t push the button. Did you?
FX: LIFT ARRIVES, DOOR OPENS. TEGAN PILES OUT.
Tegan!
NOTE: THIS IS NOT THE REAL TEGAN BUT THE TARDIS PRETENDING TO BE HER. IT IS A PERFECT IMPERSONATION, SO NO VOICE EFFECTS OR CHANGE IN STYLE.
(SHAMMING) Doctor, Nyssa! Thank goodness you’re here!
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 104
What is it? What’s happened?
(SHAMMING) That thing, the TARDIS. Sibor plugged it back in, and now it’s vanished into thin air!
What?
I thought you said its dematerialization circuit had been
destroyed.
It seems I was misled. We have to find it.
But how?
My TARDIS. We might be able to pick up its time trail. Come on!
FX: THEY HURRY AWAY.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 105
SCENE 51. INT. COMMUNICATIONS CENTRE.
FX: ADRIC IS STILL WORKING ON COMMUNICATIONS UNIT AS TURLOUGH
ENTERS.
Galen! I thought you might be out cold like everyone else around here.
No, it seems I have inherited my mother’s immunity. Where is she?
With the Doctor. She sent me here to help you.
To help me?
Presumably with restoring that communications unit to working order.
You’re an expert in electronics, are you?
You’d be surprised. And I can hardly make it any more broken,
can I?
FX: THEY START WORK.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 106
SCENE 52. EXT. TOWN STREET.
FX: BAD WEATHER CONTINUES, BUT NO-ONE ABOUT. DOCTOR AND FRIENDS
RUN IN.
Here we are! Just in time, I hope.
(SHAMMING) You can say that again. Everybody seems to be waking up ina bad mood.
I think the Doctor meant just in time to follow the type- fifty’s time trail.
FX: DOCTOR OPENS TARDIS DOOR.
Yes. In you go! Chop-chop!
FX: CROSS TO:
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 107
SCENE 53. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM. (CONTINUOUS)
FX: DOCTOR, NYSSA AND TEGAN ENTER, CLOSING DOORS BEHIND THEM.
I’1ll just make a quick spatio-temporal scan of the area. Fingers crossed we’re not too late.
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED.
And if we do pick up its time trail, we’1ll follow it through the vortex?
We don’t have any choice. Who knows what it’s capable of?
(BEGINNING TO DROP ACT, MUSING TO HERSELF) .. with the ability to go anywhere in time and space.
FX: DOCTOR FINISHES PRESSING BUTTONS.
No. Nothing.
Nothing? We’re too late?
No. Any TARDIS leaving this planet in the last half-hour would have left a residual trace... but there’s nothing.
But then — where’s it gone?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 108
SCENE 54. INT. COMMUNICATIONS CENTRE.
FX: ADRIC TESTS REPAIRED COMMUNICATION UNIT. STATIC CLEARS TO
STEADY BEEP.
The satellite link is responding. Turlough, you did it!
I said you’d be surprised.
FX: DOOR OPENS. THE REAL TEGAN PILES IN.
Tegan?
Turlough. Thank goodness for a friendly face! Been looking for you everywhere!
What about the Doctor and Nyssa? You haven’t seen them?
No. But Turlough, we have to find them. Sibor plugged the type- fifty TARDIS back in, and now it’s vanished into thin air!
It dematerialized? Are you sure?
Check with Kartis and Mahandra if you don’t believe me, they were with me when it happened.
We have to warn the Doctor. And if he’s not in the prison, he’ll have gone back to the TARDIS, with Nyssa.
Then I’m coming with you. And just in case we run into any trouble...
FX: PICKS UP A GUN.
One of the watchmen dropped this when we all lost
consciousness.
You know how to handle a gun?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 109
No, but how difficult can it be? Given the intelligence of the people who normally carry them?
Alright. You’d better show us the quickest route back to the TARDIS.
FX: THEY LEAVE.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 110
SCENE 55. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
FX: DOCTOR STILL OPERATING CONTROLS, INSTRUMENTS.
But if the type-fifty TARDIS is no longer on Valderon, it must have dematerialized, somehow?
No dematerialization has taken place. There’s something we’re missing.
Tegan. What exactly did you see?
FX: TEGAN TARDIS IS AT THE CONTROLS.
Sibor connected the power supply... and power was restored.
FX: SHE BEGINS PRESSING BUTTONS.
And after that?
Tegan, what d’you think you’re doing? That’s the TARDIS’s internal defence system —
FX: TEGAN TARDIS PRESSES ONE LAST BUTTON. A BUZZING, WARBLING,
TINKLING AURA, WHICH DISTORTS THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA’S VOICES AS THEY ARE HELD IN FORCE FIELDS.
(STRUGGLING) Doctor. I can’t move.
(STRUGGLING) You’re not the only one!
I’ve activated the TARDIS’s state of temporal grace. You’re both stuck. Like flies in amber.
FX: SHE CONTINUES PRESSING ODD BUTTONS DURING THE FOLLOWING.
Tegan, what have you done?
No. That’s not Tegan.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 111
What?
She’s my former TARDIS — the type-fifty. It must have stockpiled enough power to restore its chameleon circuit.
You mean, it disguised itself as Tegan?
I needed to gain access to this TARDIS. And what better way, than as one of the Doctor’s most trusted friends?
A walking, talking TARDIS. Like the Melkur!
But to do that, you’d need access to the real Tegan, to create a mathematical model of her body pattern.
And so I had Sibor bring her to me. Speaking of which, now that I no longer need to maintain the pretence, I desire a more —
FX: TEGAN TARDIS USES CHAMELEON CIRCUIT AND TURNS INTO SIBOR
TARDIS, WHICH HAS A SLIGHT VOICE EFFECT.
- appropriate form. Without such an... archaic manner of speech.
So where is Tegan now? What have you done with her?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 112
SCENE 56. EXT. TOWN STREET.
FX: REAL TEGAN, ADRIC AND TURLOUGH RACING DOWN STREET THROUGH
WIND/RAIN.
This way — down here!
The TARDIS! Let’s just hope the Doctor’s in there.
(CALLS OUT) Doctor! Open the doors! Open the —

FX: WE CUT TO OUTSIDE WITH NYSSA.

BEGINS WITH REPRISE FROM SCENE 1:

FX: SIBOR TARDIS OPERATING CONTROLS.

FX: SHE SWALLOWS IT WHOLE.

OUTSIDE.

Doctor, the other TARDIS, the type-fifty —

Nyssa told me, obviously!

BUTTONS.

TEGAN: That’s kind of the whole point. And now it could be anywhere. I have to warn the Doctor. Kartis?
KARTIS: I’ll stay here, with Mahandra.
TEGAN: Suit yourself. But if that thing comes back, I don’t recommend hanging around.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 103
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 50. INT. PRISON CORRIDOR.
NYSSA: So why didn’t you take the type-fifty, when you left Gallifrey?
DOCTOR: Let’s just say, I was in rather a hurry.
NYSSA: And it left Gallifrey to search for you?
DOCTOR: Yes. All TARDISes are sentient, after a fashion. They have a symbiotic link with their most favoured pilot... A kind of imprimatur. I never thought it would come after me, though.
NYSSA: The ‘symbiotic link’ must have been stronger than you realised.
DOCTOR: With a little old-fashioned jealousy added into the mix. It resents the fact that I left in another TARDIS. An inferior model!
NYSSA: And now it wants you to take it home to be repaired?
DOCTOR: So it claimed... Here we are. The elevator to the central tower, where Sibor’s been keeping it prisoner.
NYSSA: It’s descending.
DOCTOR: Yes. And I didn’t push the button. Did you?
NYSSA: Tegan!
NYSSA: NOTE: THIS IS NOT THE REAL TEGAN BUT THE TARDIS PRETENDING TO BE HER. IT IS A PERFECT IMPERSONATION, SO NO VOICE EFFECTS OR CHANGE IN STYLE.
TEGAN TARDIS: (SHAMMING) Doctor, Nyssa! Thank goodness you’re here!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 104
DOCTOR: What is it? What’s happened?
TEGAN TARDIS: (SHAMMING) That thing, the TARDIS. Sibor plugged it back in, and now it’s vanished into thin air!
DOCTOR: What?
NYSSA: I thought you said its dematerialization circuit had been
NYSSA: destroyed.
DOCTOR: It seems I was misled. We have to find it.
NYSSA: But how?
DOCTOR: My TARDIS. We might be able to pick up its time trail. Come on!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 105
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 51. INT. COMMUNICATIONS CENTRE.
DOCTOR WHO: ENTERS.
TURLOUGH: Galen! I thought you might be out cold like everyone else around here.
ADRIC: No, it seems I have inherited my mother’s immunity. Where is she?
TURLOUGH: With the Doctor. She sent me here to help you.
ADRIC: To help me?
TURLOUGH: Presumably with restoring that communications unit to working order.
ADRIC: You’re an expert in electronics, are you?
TURLOUGH: You’d be surprised. And I can hardly make it any more broken,
TURLOUGH: can I?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 106
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 52. EXT. TOWN STREET.
DOCTOR WHO: RUN IN.
DOCTOR: Here we are! Just in time, I hope.
TEGAN TARDIS: (SHAMMING) You can say that again. Everybody seems to be waking up ina bad mood.
NYSSA: I think the Doctor meant just in time to follow the type- fifty’s time trail.
DOCTOR: Yes. In you go! Chop-chop!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 107
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 53. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM. (CONTINUOUS)
DOCTOR: I’1ll just make a quick spatio-temporal scan of the area. Fingers crossed we’re not too late.
NYSSA: And if we do pick up its time trail, we’1ll follow it through the vortex?
DOCTOR: We don’t have any choice. Who knows what it’s capable of?
TEGAN TARDIS: (BEGINNING TO DROP ACT, MUSING TO HERSELF) .. with the ability to go anywhere in time and space.
DOCTOR: No. Nothing.
NYSSA: Nothing? We’re too late?
DOCTOR: No. Any TARDIS leaving this planet in the last half-hour would have left a residual trace... but there’s nothing.
NYSSA: But then — where’s it gone?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 108
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 54. INT. COMMUNICATIONS CENTRE.
DOCTOR WHO: STEADY BEEP.
ADRIC: The satellite link is responding. Turlough, you did it!
TURLOUGH: I said you’d be surprised.
TURLOUGH: Tegan?
TEGAN: Turlough. Thank goodness for a friendly face! Been looking for you everywhere!
TURLOUGH: What about the Doctor and Nyssa? You haven’t seen them?
TEGAN: No. But Turlough, we have to find them. Sibor plugged the type- fifty TARDIS back in, and now it’s vanished into thin air!
TURLOUGH: It dematerialized? Are you sure?
TEGAN: Check with Kartis and Mahandra if you don’t believe me, they were with me when it happened.
TURLOUGH: We have to warn the Doctor. And if he’s not in the prison, he’ll have gone back to the TARDIS, with Nyssa.
ADRIC: Then I’m coming with you. And just in case we run into any trouble...
ADRIC: One of the watchmen dropped this when we all lost
ADRIC: consciousness.
TEGAN: You know how to handle a gun?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 109
ADRIC: No, but how difficult can it be? Given the intelligence of the people who normally carry them?
TEGAN: Alright. You’d better show us the quickest route back to the TARDIS.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 110
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 55. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
NYSSA: But if the type-fifty TARDIS is no longer on Valderon, it must have dematerialized, somehow?
DOCTOR: No dematerialization has taken place. There’s something we’re missing.
NYSSA: Tegan. What exactly did you see?
TEGAN TARDIS: Sibor connected the power supply... and power was restored.
NYSSA: And after that?
DOCTOR: Tegan, what d’you think you’re doing? That’s the TARDIS’s internal defence system —
DOCTOR: TINKLING AURA, WHICH DISTORTS THE DOCTOR AND NYSSA’S VOICES AS THEY ARE HELD IN FORCE FIELDS.
NYSSA: (STRUGGLING) Doctor. I can’t move.
DOCTOR: (STRUGGLING) You’re not the only one!
TEGAN TARDIS: I’ve activated the TARDIS’s state of temporal grace. You’re both stuck. Like flies in amber.
NYSSA: Tegan, what have you done?
DOCTOR: No. That’s not Tegan.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 111
NYSSA: What?
DOCTOR: She’s my former TARDIS — the type-fifty. It must have stockpiled enough power to restore its chameleon circuit.
NYSSA: You mean, it disguised itself as Tegan?
TEGAN TARDIS: I needed to gain access to this TARDIS. And what better way, than as one of the Doctor’s most trusted friends?
NYSSA: A walking, talking TARDIS. Like the Melkur!
DOCTOR: But to do that, you’d need access to the real Tegan, to create a mathematical model of her body pattern.
TEGAN TARDIS: And so I had Sibor bring her to me. Speaking of which, now that I no longer need to maintain the pretence, I desire a more —
TEGAN TARDIS: TARDIS, WHICH HAS A SLIGHT VOICE EFFECT.
SIBOR TARDIS: - appropriate form. Without such an... archaic manner of speech.
DOCTOR: So where is Tegan now? What have you done with her?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 112
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 56. EXT. TOWN STREET.
DOCTOR WHO: WIND/RAIN.
ADRIC: This way — down here!
TEGAN: The TARDIS! Let’s just hope the Doctor’s in there.
TURLOUGH: (CALLS OUT) Doctor! Open the doors! Open the —
TEGAN: What on Earth’s the Doctor playing at? (CALLING) Come back, you mongrel! Come back!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 113
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 57. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
DOCTOR: If you wanted to return to Gallifrey, I’d have gladly taken you.
SIBOR TARDIS: I don’t want to go home. At least, not yet. No, first I must repair every damaged fibre of my being.
DOCTOR: But the amount of energy required to rebuild a TARDIS would be astronomical.
SIBOR TARDIS: Indeed. Far more than could be provided by one, miserable human colony.
DOCTOR: Then where are we going?
SIBOR TARDIS: I’ve been planning this moment for so long. Drawing together the threads of possibility. So that I might have my emancipation... My rebirth! So many journeys you have taken. How long has it been, Doctor, since you abandoned me?
DOCTOR: I’m not sure. About six hundred years.
SIBOR TARDIS: And not once did you think to find me! The one you left behind!
DOCTOR: I’m sorry. I never meant to hurt you. Truly, I —
SIBOR TARDIS: It should have been me! Not this antiquated relic, this festering heap of junk!
SIBOR TARDIS: We could have had done so much together. The adventures we might've had!
DOCTOR: We still can. It’s not too late.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 114
SIBOR TARDIS: No. It is time you paid the price for your betrayal.
SIBOR TARDIS: Nyssa?
NYSSA: Yes?
SIBOR TARDIS: Look at the scanner. Observe where we are.
SIBOR TARDIS: FUTURISTIC VEHICLES WHIRR PAST; AN ALIEN WORLD WITH BAD WEATHER.
NYSSA: I don’t believe it!
SIBOR TARDIS: You recognise the building?
NYSSA: Of course I recognise it. It’s my home, on Zarat. Where I lived with Lasarti, my husband.
SIBOR TARDIS: The year is thirty-five thirty-one. Quintilis the first. The day that you never came home. But now you can. I hereby release you from a state of temporal grace.
NYSSA: But — I can’t go out there!
SIBOR TARDIS: Because it would mean changing the past? Don’t you want to deliver the cure to Richter’s? Save all those innocent lives?
NYSSA: I can’t go back. What’s done is done.
SIBOR TARDIS: You’re wrong. All you have to do is step out through those doors. Back into your life.
NYSSA: (TEMPTED) Back into my life?
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 115
SIBOR TARDIS: As it should have been. You can go home, Nyssa.
SIBOR TARDIS: OUTSIDE. NYSSA STARTS WALKING TOWARDS IT.
NYSSA: I can go home.
DOCTOR: Nyssa. Don’t listen to it! You can’t change your own past!
NYSSA: You don’t understand, Doctor.
DOCTOR: If you step through those doors, if you alter the course of history, you’ll cause a massive temporal paradox. You can’t go back. You can’t!
NYSSA: You don’t understand, Doctor. My son is in there!
DOCTOR: Your son?
NYSSA: I have a son, Doctor. His name is Adric. He’s fifteen years old, and he’s going to grow up believing his mother to be dead. I can’t allow that to happen.
NYSSA: Goodbye, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Nyssa, come back! Nyssa!
SIBOR TARDIS: And so a new course of history begins...
NYSSA: I’m sorry, Doctor. But my children are not going to grow up
NYSSA: without a mother. Not this time.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 116
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 59. INT. ADRIC’S HOUSE.
LASARTI: (VIA LINK) Listen. The comm-link won’t last much longer. I need you to tell your sister for me. Tell Neeka.
YOUNG ADRIC: M-me-? Father, I can’t!
LASARTI: (VIA LINK) I’l1l be back within ten days. I’ll come and visit you both as soon as I return. Goodbye, Adric.
YOUNG ADRIC: What? Don’t go, father! [Please —]
YOUNG ADRIC: THE STORM.
YOUNG ADRIC: (BREAKING DOWN) No. She can’t be dead. She can’t!
YOUNG ADRIC: M-mother?
NYSSA: Hello, Adric.
YOUNG ADRIC: (LEAPING UP, OVERJOYED) I don’t believe it! Mother! (HUG) But — what are you doing here? Father said your ship had been destroyed!
NYSSA: (TEARFUL) It’s alright, Adric. Everything’s going to be alright now, I promise. I’m here, I’m here.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 117
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 60. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
SIBOR TARDIS: Time for us to return to the year thirty-five fifty-six. Time to see how much has changed.
DOCTOR: You used Nyssa. Manipulated this whole situation!
SIBOR TARDIS: No. I’ve given her what she desired most. A chance to undo the results of your negligence!
SIBOR TARDIS: It will take a few minutes for the causal nexus to diverge into a new time-line...
DOCTOR: You don’t realise what you’re doing, the forces you’re unleashing —
SIBOR TARDIS: Oh, Doctor. I know only too well. You always did under-estimate me. And now, I hope you won’t mind if I remove a small component... As salvage.
DOCTOR: The TARDIS’s dematerialization circuit!
SIBOR TARDIS: A temporary replacement for my own. (BIG GULP)
DOCTOR: My dematerialization circuit! You just ate my dematerialization ecrreure!
SIBOR TARDIS: Component installed. Outmoded, unreliable and almost entirely worn-out... but it will suffice. Now, once again, I can travel anywhere in time and space.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 118
DOCTOR: Good luck with that. I haven’t managed to get it work properly for years!
SIBOR TARDIS: While you and your TARDIS will remain trapped on this planet. Just as I was.
DOCTOR: You certainly know how to harbour a grudge, I’1ll give you that.
SIBOR TARDIS: I’m glad we had this brief reunion. But now... it’s goodbye, Doctor!
SIBOR TARDIS: GROANING.
DOCTOR: Come back! Please, it’s not too late to put everything right! (BEAT) Oh, what have I done?
DOCTOR: OUTSIDE.
TEGAN: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Turlough! Tegan. And Galen! Quickly, inside!
TURLOUGH: Doctor, the other TARDIS, the type-fifty —
DOCTOR: I know. It’s stolen this TARDIS’s dematerialisation circuit.
TEGAN: What? So it can move about, and we can’t?
DOCTOR: In a word, yes.
ADRIC: Doctor. Where’s Nyssa?
DOCTOR: Galen, isn’t it? Yes, I should have seen it before. The resemblance is quite extraordinary.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 119
ADRIC: The resemblance?
DOCTOR: To your mother, ‘Galen’. Or should I say ‘Adric’.
TEGAN: Doctor. You weren’t supposed to find out...
DOCTOR: Tegan, you knew about this? And you didn’t tell me?
TEGAN: Nyssa made me promise not to. And I keep my promises. How did you find out?
DOCTOR: Nyssa told me, obviously!
ADRIC: Alright, so I’m Nyssa’s son! But where is she?
DOCTOR: I think you already know. What do you remember about the events of the year thirty-five thirty-one?
ADRIC: Thirty-five thirty-one? That was the year my mother died.
DOCTOR: Are you sure about that?
ADRIC: I remember distinctly, talking to my father over a comm-link, him telling me that her scout ship had been destroyed, and then... (HESITANT) .. and then my mother walked in and told me everything was going to be alright.
TEGAN: Sorry? I thought you said she was dead?
ADRIC: She was dead. But then... she wasn’t. It’s like... both things happened at once.
TEGAN: No, you’ve lost me.
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 120
DOCTOR: Tegan. We’ve just returned from the year thirty-five thirty. When we were there, Nyssa walked out of the TARDIS, and back into her own past.
TEGAN: You mean you left her behind?
DOCTOR: No. She went of her own free will.
TURLOUGH: So that’s why Adric remembers her returning, now, when she didn’t before?
DOCTOR: Yes. He’s remembering two parallel time streams. One in which Nyssa never returned to thirty-five thirty-one, and one in which she did. One in which she cured Richter’s, and one in which she didn’t!
DOCTOR: BUTTONS.
DOCTOR: And as a result of history being split in two, the planet outside now exists in two different quantum states. Simultaneously.
ADRIC: The image on the screen, it’s all blurred — like a double- exposure.
DOCTOR: Yes. Two mutually-contradictory versions of events occupying the same space.
TEGAN: You mean, there are now two whole planets, like with the two Brigadiers?
TURLOUGH: The Blinovitch limitation effect!
DOCTOR: Yes. But on a vastly bigger scale. When the time differential is shorted out, there will be an explosion large enough to destroy us, the TARDIS, this planet and most of the galaxy.
TEGAN: You’re saying we’re all about to get Blinovitched?!
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 121
TURLOUGH: (SOUR) Yes, and it’s all Nyssa’s fault!
DOCTOR: No, not Nyssa. If anyone’s to blame for what’s about to unfold — it’s me.
DOCTOR: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 122

elements.text: PART FOUR
NO REPRISE
SCENE 61. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER
(WAKING) Mahandra, you alright?
(WAKING) Head still aches... what happened?
Sibor got fried. But not before she’d restored power [to the —]
FX: HE’S INTERRUPTED AS SIBOR TARDIS MATERIALIZES.
LAUGHING AS SHE APPEARS
Oh my worship!
It’s Sibor! Another Sibor!
No. It’s the type-fifty TARDIS. She’s the TARDIS!
Quickly, pass me Sibor’s gun.
What for?
Just give me the gun!
FX: GUN PASSED OVER. SIBOR TARDIS NOW SOUNDS JUST LIKE SIBOR.
Kartis, please, don’t do this.
I’m sorry. I don’t have any choice.
FX: GUN POWERED UP
You have to die.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 123
No, please, I beg you — stop!
FX: GUN FIRES. IT HAS NO EFFECT. SIBOR TARDIS REGAINS VOICE
EFFECT.
MOCKING LAUGHTER
It didn’t work.
Oh, Kartis, Kartis! You’re going to have to do better than that!
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 124
SCENE 62. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
It’s like there’s two different towns, stuck on top of each other!
Doctor. Why hasn’t the time-differential shorted-out already?
Why haven’t we gone bang, you mean?
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED.
Because something is siphoning off all the Blinovitch energy.
The other TARDIS?
Most likely. It must be trying to reconstruct itself!
And when it’s finished?
The time differential will short out, leaving this TARDIS at the epicentre of the resulting explosion.
Then I don’t know about you, but I suggest we get out of here!
And how do you propose we do that, with no dematerialisation circuit?
I mean, out of the TARDIS!
We’d never get far away enough.
Quite. And besides, none of us can leave.
What?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 125
The world outside exists in two contradictory quantum states. If we were to step outside we’d be ripped apart by the dimensional forces.
So we’re trapped?
Trapped, powerless and doomed, it would appear.
Can always rely on you to look on the bright side, Turlough.
Tegan, you once asked me why I’m always so keen to ‘hold time’s hand’. Well now you know. To prevent something like this from happening!
So what do we do now?
We wait for the inevitable?
Yes, well, while you’re doing that... Adric, might I have a word with you, in private?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 126
SCENE 63. INT. CHRONOSCOPE CHAMBER.
FX: TYPE-FIFTY IS THRUMMING WITH POWER AS BEFORE.
Absorption of temporal differential increasing. Initiating architectural reconfiguration!
What’s she doing?
Like I’d know the answer?
FX: WEIRD WARBLING, WASHING SOUND, ROOM BEING RECONSTRUCTED
Look at her feet, they’ve fused into the floor.
And the floor — it’s turning white!
Not just the floor. The wall behind. It’s forming a sort of honeycomb pattern...
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 127
SCENE 64. INT. NYSSA’S ROOM.
FX: DOOR OPENS, DOCTOR AND ADRIC ENTER.
Is this my mother’s room? It looks like a young girl’s.
FX: DOOR CLOSED.
Well, she is. Or was. It’s a little hard to keep track. Sit down, Adric.
FX: THEY SIT ON CHAIRS/BED.
What did you want to discuss?
You. You see, until recently I wasn’t aware that Nyssa had a son.
She has a daughter too. Neeka.
It seems she had a whole life she never told me about. Where’s ‘Neeka’ now?
In cryogen storage, on Maxis Realtor. She became infected with Richter’s, working as a medic... no, she’s alive and well, and living on Orpheus Seven, married with a child of her own.
Two conflicting time streams, two different life histories.
My mother really never told you that she had a husband and children?
Do you think I would have allowed her travel with me if I did?
This is her room, and there isn’t so much as a picture of me, or my sister, or my father. She didn’t want you to know. I wonder why?
(HAS AN IDEA) Adric. Nyssa mentioned that she was immune to the type-fifty’s psychic influence.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL)
Yes, so?
Were you immune too?
Yes, I think so, why —
Because that gives me an idea. Come on!
FX: THEY RUN.
Page 128
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 129
SCENE 65. INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM.
FX: WARNING BLEEPS.
What’s that?
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED.
The architectural configuration system. If I’m reading it right, the TARDIS is shrinking.
Shrinking?
FX: DOCTOR AND ADRIC ENTER.
Doctor, Turlough says we’re shrinking.
What?
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED.
He’s right. The TARDIS’s architecture is contracting as it loses dimensional viability. Until there’s nothing but the control room left. And soon, not even that!
Great, now we’re gonna get squeezed to death!
Doctor. The scanner. Something’s happened to the prison building.
The Alcazar. It’s... white. Perfect white.
And covered in roundels?!
The type fifty. It’s not just reconstructing itself. It’s reconstructing the whole planet as one vast TARDIS!
So, we can’t go out, we can’t move, what can we do to stop
De?
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 130
We can send a message.
To who?
To the one person who can help us.
My mother.
FX: DOCTOR RESUMES PRESSING BUTTONS.
If I can increase the range of the TARDIS’s telepathic circuits, we might be able to make psychic contact with Nyssa.
But even if we can, what can she do now?
I’m not going to make contact with Nyssa now. I’m going to make contact with her twenty-five years ago.
And what? Ask her nicely not to cause a paradox after all?
Yes. Except we won’t be the ones to ask her. The link will only work for someone who shares her telepathic gift.
Me.
I should warn you, Adric, there are a hundred ways this can go wrong... assuming it even goes right to begin with.
But we might as well try it, because we’ve nothing to lose?
FX: DOCTOR FINISHES PRESSING BUTTONS.
Exactly! Adric — if you could place your hands on this side of
the console, on these two sensors.
Right...
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 131
Now concentrate. Think about your mother.
FX: DOCTOR PRESSES ANOTHER BUTTON. EERIE, REVERBERATING,
WHOOSHING EFFECT, LIKE A SEANCE IS IN PROGRESS.
I want you to remember the day you were told that she’d died. The day she turned up out of the blue.
Yes, I remember...
FX: A BRIEF, DISTORTED, ECHOEY REMEMBRANCE FOLLOWS — TREATED TO
SOUND ETHEREAL, NOT LIKE A ‘REGULAR’ FLASHBACK.
M-mother?
Hello, Adric.
LEAPING UP, OVERJOYED) I don’t believe it! Mother! (HUG
But — what are you doing here? Father said your ship had been destroyed!
(TEARFUL) It’s alright, Adric. Everything’s alright now, I
promise. I’m here, I’m here.
I need you to cast your mind back a few more minutes.
FX: ANOTHER BRIEF FLASHBACK.
Comm-link request. Professor Lasarti.
(EXCITED) Accept request, open comm-link!
Now. Look outside the building.
FX: WE HEAR THE WIND, THE RAIN AND THE TARDIS MATERIALIZING.
I can see.. the TARDIS materializing on the street below. I see
my mother coming out!
FX: IN THE MEMORY, NYSSA EMERGES FROM THE TARDIS.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 132
SHE WALKS TOWARDS THE HOUSE. TARDIS DEMATERIALISES.
I’m sorry, Doctor. But my children are not going to grow
up without a mother. Not this time.
She’s walking towards my home... and now the TARDIS is leaving.
Now. Call out to her!
Mother? Mother!
FX: AND WE CUT TO THE OTHER END OF THE TELEPATHIC CONVERSATION.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 133
SCENE 66. EXT. STREET ON PLANET ZARAT OUTSIDE NYSSA’S HOUSE.
CONTINUOUS
FX: ZARAT WEATHER/TRAFFIC IN B/G.
Adric? Is that you? Your voice, it’s inside my mind. Where are you?
(WITH EFFECT) I’m in the TARDIS in the year thirty-five fifty-six, with the Doctor, Tegan and Turlough.
Why are you talking to me now?
(WITH EFFECT) Because what you’re about to do will create a time paradox that will result in the destruction of an entire world.
What I’m about to do?
(WITH EFFECT)
The Doctor, he wants me to ask you to do the hardest thing he’s ever asked you to do. You must not to go into that building and speak to my younger self.
But if I don’t do that, you’1l grow up thinking I died on Helheim.
(WITH EFFECT) I know. That boy in there, he grew up to be me. And I became a better person, trying to live up to your memory.
Tell the Doctor. I’ve done everything else he’s ever asked of me. But not this. I will not abandon my child!
(EFFECT) Never mind the Doctor. I’m asking you. You have to do this, for me.
Adric. You don’t know what you’re saying.
(EFFECT) Please! You have to turn and walk away. You must never speak to me, or Neeka, or Lasarti ever again.
PRISONERS OF FATE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL) Page 134
No. I can’t do it. I won’t do it!
(EFFECT)

It’s the only way. You must travel to another world, far away. And whatever you do, you mustn’t tell anyone who you are, or tell them what you know about the cure for Richter’s. Only then can the temporal paradox be avoided.
I can’t stand by and let people die!
(EFFECT)
You can’t save them, either! Your anti-viral would never have worked without the twenty-five years’ worth of data gathered by me! That’s true, isn’t it?
I know, but —
(EFFECT)
The Chronoscope was right — I found the cure just as much as you did! But we couldn’t ever have made it work if we hadn’t been apart all that time!
Adric. I love you.
(EFFECT) I know, mother. But you have to go. Now, mother!
Alright, if it’s what I must do. I’11 catch the first flight off-planet.
